9. The "CBS Evening News" began its broadcasts there with Douglas Edwards.
10. Many historic news events were broadcast from this location, such as John Glenn's Mercury-Atlas 6 space mission and Walter Cronkite's coverage of the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
11. Edward R. Murrow's "See It Now" originated from Grand Central, including his famous broadcasts on Senator Joseph McCarthy.
12. The Murrow broadcasts were recreated in George Clooney's movie "Good Night, and Good Luck", although the CBS News and corporate offices were not actually in the same building as the film implies.
13. The long-running panel show "What's My Line?"
14. was first broadcast from the GCT studios, as were "The Goldbergs" and "Mama".
15. The facility's operations were later moved to the CBS Broadcast Center.
16. In 1966, the former studio space was converted to a sports club with two tennis courts and was operated by Donald Trump from 1984 to 2009.
17. The space is currently occupied by a conductor lounge and a smaller sports facility with a single tennis court.

Category: Travel
Title: Magic Kingdom
Section: Main Street, U.S.A.

1. Symbolically, Main Street, U.S.A. represents the park's "opening credits," where guests pass under the train station (the opening curtain,) then view the names of key personnel along the windows of the buildings' upper floors.
2. Many windows bear the name of a fictional business, such as "Seven Summits Expeditions, Frank G. Wells President", with each representing a tribute to significant people connected to the Disney company and the development of the Walt Disney World Resort.
3. It features stylistic influences from around the country.
4. Taking its inspiration from New England to Missouri, this design is most noticeable in the four corners in the middle of Main Street, where each of the four corner buildings represents a different architectural style.
5. There is no opera house as there is at Disneyland; instead, there is the Town Square Theater.
6. Also, this is where Christopher George Weaver, the "mayor" of Main Street U.S.A., and one of the park's most important figures, resides.Main Street is lined with shops selling merchandise and food.
7. The decor is early-20th century small-town America, inspired by Walt Disney's childhood and the film "Lady and the Tramp".
8. City Hall contains the Guest Relations lobby, where cast members provide information and assistance.
9. A working barber shop gives haircuts for a fee.
10. The Emporium carries a wide variety of Disney souvenirs such as plush toys, collectible pins and Mickey-ear hats.
11. Tony’s Town Square Restaurant and The Plaza Restaurant are table-service locations.
12. At the end of Main Street is Casey's Corner, where guests enjoy traditional American ballpark fare including hot dogs and fries while watching old cartoons on the bleachers.
13. The Main Street Confectionary sells sweets priced by their weight, such as candied apples, crisped rice treats, chocolates, cookies and fudge.
14. Most windows bear the name of people who were influential at Disney parks.
15. An example of a classic Main Street, U.S.A. attraction is the narrow gauge Walt Disney World Railroad, which transports guest throughout the park, making stops at Main Street, U.S.A., Fantasyland, and Frontierland.
16. The railroad's previous stop at Mickey's Toontown Fair was replaced by the Fantasyland stop in 2012.
17. Main Street, U.S.A. also has the Main Street Vehicles attraction, which includes a narrow gauge tramway with horse-drawn streetcars, and several old-fashioned motor vehicles.In the distance beyond the end of Main Street stands Cinderella Castle.
18. Though only 189 feet (55m) tall, it benefits from a technique known as forced perspective.
19. The second stories of all the buildings along Main Street are shorter than the first stories, and the third stories are even shorter than the second, and the top windows of the castle are much smaller than they appear.
20. The resulting visual effect is that the buildings appear to be larger and taller than they really are.The park contains two additional tributes: the "Partners" statue of Walt Disney and Mickey Mouse in front of Cinderella Castle and the "Sharing the Magic" statue of Roy O. Disney sitting with Minnie Mouse in the Town Square section of Main Street, U.S.A.
21. Both were sculpted by veteran Imagineer Blaine Gibson.
22. In 2012, Disney replaced the shop in the Firehouse with a sign up for the Sorcerers of the Magic Kingdom game.

Category: Travel
Title: Magic Kingdom
Section: Planned film

1. In 2010, director Jon Favreau and Walt Disney Pictures had a plan to produce and release a film concerning a family at Disneyland which finds the theme park characters and attractions coming to life.
2. Favreau, who said "the Disney iconography was probably the first set of archetypes that I was exposed to" and that Disney movies and attractions "made a deep impression on me as a child", noted that, "When I first heard about the ['Magic Kingdom' film] project, I was on my way to visit Disneyland with my family.
3. I took notes and had no problem filling a book with all the ideas that this concept offered, even on first blush.
4. "Marc Abraham and Eric Newman of Strike Entertainment were scheduled to produce the film.
5. Writer-producer Ronald D. Moore had previously written an original script for the project, which the studio eventually declined to use, stating that Favreau and a new screenwriter would develop a new script.
6. On June 20, 2011, novelist Michael Chabon signed on to write the film's script.

Category: Travel
Title: Forbidden City
Section: Walls and gates

1. The Forbidden City is surrounded by a high city wall and a deep by wide moat.
2. The walls are wide at the base, tapering to at the top.
3. These walls served as both defensive walls and retaining walls for the palace.
4. They were constructed with a rammed earth core, and surfaced with three layers of specially baked bricks on both sides, with the interstices filled with mortar.At the four corners of the wall sit towers (E) with intricate roofs boasting 72 ridges, reproducing the Pavilion of Prince Teng and the Yellow Crane Pavilion as they appeared in Song dynasty paintings.
5. These towers are the most visible parts of the palace to commoners outside the walls, and much folklore is attached to them.
6. According to one legend, artisans could not put a corner tower back together after it was dismantled for renovations in the early Qing dynasty, and it was only rebuilt after the intervention of carpenter-immortal Lu Ban.The wall is pierced by a gate on each side.
7. At the southern end is the main Meridian Gate (A).
8. To the north is the Gate of Divine Might (B), which faces Jingshan Park.
9. The east and west gates are called the "East Glorious Gate" (D) and "West Glorious Gate" (C).
10. All gates in the Forbidden City are decorated with a nine-by-nine array of golden door nails, except for the East Glorious Gate, which has only eight rows.The Meridian Gate has two protruding wings forming three sides of a square (Wumen, or Meridian Gate, Square) before it.
11. The gate has five gateways.
12. The central gateway is part of the Imperial Way, a stone flagged path that forms the central axis of the Forbidden City and the ancient city of Beijing itself, and leads all the way from the Gate of China in the south to Jingshan in the north.
13. Only the Emperor may walk or ride on the Imperial Way, except for the Empress on the occasion of her wedding, and successful students after the Imperial Examination.

Category: Travel
Title: Forbidden City
Section: Influence

1. The Forbidden City, the culmination of the two-thousand-year development of classical Chinese and East Asian architecture, has been influential in the subsequent development of Chinese architecture, as well as providing inspiration for many artistic works.
2. Some specific examples include:
3. •    Depiction in art, film, literature and popular culture

4. The Forbidden City has served as the scene to many works of fiction.
5. In recent years, it has been depicted in films and television series.
6. Some notable examples include:
7. •     "The Forbidden City" (1918), a fiction film about a Chinese emperor and an American.
8. •     "The Last Emperor" (1987), a biographical film about Puyi, was the first feature film ever authorised by the government of the People's Republic of China to be filmed in the Forbidden City.
9. •     "Marco Polo" a joint NBC and RAI TV miniseries broadcast in the early 1980s, was filmed inside the Forbidden City.
10. Note, however, that the present Forbidden City did not exist in the Yuan dynasty, when Marco Polo met Kublai Khan.
11. •    Performance venue

12. The Forbidden City has also served as a performance venue.
13. However, its use for this purpose is strictly limited, due to the heavy impact of equipment and performance on the ancient structures.
14. Almost all performances said to be "in the Forbidden City" are held outside the palace walls.
15. •     Giacomo Puccini's opera, "Turandot", the story of a Chinese princess, was performed at the Imperial Shrine just outside the Forbidden City for the first time in 1998.
16. •     In 1997, Greek-born composer and keyboardist Yanni performed a live concert in front of the Forbidden City.
17. The concert was recorded and later released as part of the "Tribute" album.
18. •     In 2001, the Three Tenors, Spanish singers Plácido Domingo and José Carreras and the Italian singer Luciano Pavarotti sang in front of Forbidden City main gate as one of their performances.
19. •     In 2004, the French musician Jean Michel Jarre performed a live concert in front of the Forbidden City, accompanied by 260 musicians, as part of the "Year of France in China" festivities.

Category: Travel
Title: Grand Bazaar, Istanbul
Section: Architecture

1. The Iç Bedesten has a rectangular plan (43.30 m x 29.50 m).
2. Two rows of stone piers, four in each row, sustain three rows of bays, five in each row.
3. Each bay is surmounted by a brick dome with blind drum.
4. In the inner and in the outer walls have been built 44 cellars (), vaulted rooms without external openings.
5. The sunlight in Bedesten comes from rectangular windows placed right under the roof: they can be accessed through a wooden ambulatory.
6. Due to the scarce illumination, the edifice was kept open only some hours each day, and was devoted to the trade of luxury goods, above all textiles.
7. Moreover, the Bedesten's Mahzen were also used as safes.
8. The building can be accessed through four gates:
9. •     “Second-hand Book Sellers’ Gate” () in the north,
10. •     “Skullcap Sellers’ Gate” () in the south,
11. •     “Jewellers’ Gate” () in the east, and;
12. •     “Women’s Clothiers’ Gate” () in the west.

13. The Sandal Bedesten has also a rectangular plan (40.20 m × 42.20 m), with 12 stone piers bearing 20 bays surmounted by brick domes with blind drum.
14. In this case shops are carved only in the outer walls.
15. In both edifices, each bay is tied to the others through brick arches tied by juniper beams, and masonry is made with rubble.
16. Both buildings were closed by Iron gates.Aside the Bedesten, originally the Grand Bazaar structures were built with wood, and only after the 1700 fire, they were rebuilt in stone and brickwork, and covered.
17. All the bazaar edifices, except the fur dealers market (), a later addition which is two-story, are one story.
18. The roofs are mainly covered with tiles, while the part burnt in 1954 uses now tarmac.
19. In the bazaar no artificial light was foreseen, also to prevent fires, and smoking was strictly prohibited.
20. The roads outside the inner Bedesten are roughly parallel to it.
21. Anyway, the damages caused by the many fires and quakes along the centuries, together with the repairs done without a general plan, gave to the market - especially in its western part - a picturesque appearance, with its maze of roads and lanes crossing each other at various angles.

Category: Travel
Title: Grand Bazaar, Istanbul
Section: The Grand Bazaar today

1. Today the Grand Bazaar is a thriving complex, employing 26,000 people visited by between 250,000 and 400,000 visitors daily, and one of the major landmarks of Istanbul.
2. It must compete with modern shopping malls common in Istanbul, but its beauty and fascination represent a formidable advantage for it.
3. The head of the Grand Bazaar Artisans Association claimed that the complex was in 2011 - the year of its 550th birthday - the most visited monument in the world.
4. A restoration project starting in 2012 should renew its infrastructure, heating and lighting systems.
5. Moreover, the "han"s inside the Market will be renovated and later additions will be demolished.
6. This project should finally solve the big problems of the market: for example, in the whole Bazaar there is no proper toilet facility.
7. Moreover, the lacks of controls in the past years allowed many dealers to remove columns and skive walls in their shops to gain space: This, together with the substitution of lead (stolen in the last years) with concrete on the market's roof, has created a great hazard when the earthquake expected in Istanbul in the next years will occur.The Grand Bazaar is opened each day except Sundays and bank holidays from 9:00 until 19:00.

Category: Travel
Title: Tokyo Disneyland
Section: Future of Disneyland Tokyo

1. Since the park opened in 1983, Disney Tokyo has regularly been the most profitable Disney Resort.
2. By 1994, over 140 million people had entered through the gates of Tokyo Disneyland (the population of Japan is only 127.6 million) and the popularity has only increased.
3. Just two years later, it employed 12,390 people, marking Disneyland Tokyo as the biggest workplace in Japan’s diversionary outings.
4. Though the attendance is similar to that of other Japanese theme parks, the revenue produced by Tokyo Disney is larger than all other national theme parks combined, thus greatly profiting the Japanese economy.
5. Many speculate that Disney Tokyo is such an economic success due to timing and location; the theme park lies in a metropolitan area with a population of 30 million and opened at the height of a booming economy where hard-working citizens desired a fun escape from reality.
6. One of the main goals of Tokyo Japan is to ever improve the park and grow away from the restrictions of American Disney.
7. Recently Japan has been merging their national identity with the Disneyland Park by adding attractions with distinctly Japanese qualities.
8. Cinderella Castle displays the classic Disney character and story plot yet presents the story through the eyes of the Japanese.
9. Meet the World, located in World Bazaar, shows true national identity and pride as it embodies Japanese history; instead of classic Disney characters, Meet the world characters wear the traditional Japanese Kimono.
10. Once nominated by Disney Legends, Masatomo Takahashi, the former president of The Oriental Land Company, states this growth and development as one as their primary goals: “We must not just repeat what we receive from Disney.
11. I am convinced that we must contribute to the cultural exchange between Japan and U.S.A."

Category: Travel
Title: Tokyo Disneyland
Section: Ticket price

1. The ticket prices vary from one package to another and these can be found at the company's website.Standard one and two day tickets do not allow park hopping to Tokyo DisneySea, must be used on consecutive days and are date specific.
2. Instead users must state upon purchase the dates they wish to visit each park.
3. Three and Four day tickets allow park hopping on the third and fourth days, but again must be used consecutively.
4. Annual passes are available for either a single or both parks, though require a considerable number of visits to achieve a saving over regular day tickets.
5. A night pass is also available for a discounted price during the night hours only.

Category: Travel
Title: Notre Dame de Paris
Section: Architecture

1. Notre-Dame de Paris was among the first buildings in the world to use the flying buttress (arched exterior supports).
2. The building was not originally designed to include the flying buttresses around the choir and nave but after the construction began, the thinner walls (popularized in the Gothic style) grew ever higher and stress fractures began to occur as the walls pushed outward.
3. In response, the cathedral's architects built supports around the outside walls, and later additions continued the pattern.Many small individually crafted statues were placed around the outside to serve as column supports and water spouts.
4. Among these are the famous gargoyles, designed for water run-off, and chimeras.
5. The statues were originally colored as was most of the exterior.
6. The paint has worn off, but the gray stone was once covered with vivid colors.
7. The cathedral was essentially complete by 1345.
8. The cathedral has a narrow climb of 387 steps at the top of several spiral staircases; along the climb it is possible to view its most famous bell and its gargoyles in close quarters, as well as having a spectacular view across Paris when reaching the top.
9. The design of St. Peter's Anglican Cathedral in Adelaide, Australia was inspired by Notre-Dame de Paris.

Category: Travel
Title: Notre Dame de Paris
Section: Timeline of construction

1. •     1160 Maurice de Sully (named Bishop of Paris), orders the original cathedral demolished.
2. •     1163 Cornerstone laid for Notre-Dame de Paris, construction begins.
3. •     1182 Apse and choir completed.
4. •     1196 Bishop Maurice de Sully dies.
5. •     c.1200 Work begins on western facade.
6. •     1208 Bishop Eudes de Sully dies.
7. Nave vaults nearing completion.
8. •     1225 Western facade completed.
9. •     1250 Western towers and north rose window completed.
10. •     c.1245–1260s Transepts remodelled in the Rayonnant style by Jean de Chelles then Pierre de Montreuil
11. •     1250–1345 Remaining elements completed

Category: Travel
Title: Golden Gate Park
Section: Windmills

1. In 1902, the parks commission authorized construction of two windmills to pump subterranean water to supply the park.
2. The first, on the north side of the park facing the Pacific Ocean, was completed in 1903 and became known first as the North Windmill and later as the Dutch Windmill; it is now paired with the Queen Wilhelmina Tulip Garden.
3. The second, Murphy's Windmill, on the south side of the park, began operation in 1908.
4. They operated for several decades, but fell into disrepair after the park switched to electric water pumps.
5. The Dutch Windmill was restored in 1981, with Murphy's Windmill's restoration completed in September 2011.

Category: Travel
Title: Golden Gate Park
Section: Homeless camps

1. The City of San Francisco has sometimes grappled with what to do about camps of homeless people living in Golden Gate Park, which have been criticized as unsanitary, and "demoralizing" for park users and workers.
2. The camps have been described by journalists as full of garbage, broken glass, hypodermic needles, and human excrement, and the people in them are described as suffering from serious addictions and often behaving aggressively with police and park gardeners.
3. There have been occasional incidents of violence against homeless people in the park, including the 2010 park beating to death of a homeless man and an attack on park visitors by dogs owned by a park resident, also in 2010.
4. In the 1990s, then-Mayor Willie Brown sought unsuccessfully to borrow the Oakland Police Department's helicopters in order to find homeless people's camps.Starting in 1988 under then-mayor Art Agnos, and continuing under the direction of subsequent mayors including Frank Jordan, Willie Brown, and Gavin Newsom, San Francisco police have conducted intermittent sweeps of the park aimed at eliminating the camps.
5. Tactics have included information campaigns designed to inform homeless residents about city services available to help them; waking sleeping homeless people and making them leave the park; issuing citations for infractions and misdemeanors such as camping, trespassing, or public intoxication, which carry penalties of $75 to $100; and the seizure and removal from the park of homeless people's possessions.The crackdowns have been criticized by anti-poverty activists and civil liberties groups, who say they attack only the symptoms of homelessness while ignoring its root causes, and criminalize the poor for their poverty while ignoring their property rights and constitutional rights.
6. In 2006, the American Civil Liberties Union brought a lawsuit against the city government on behalf of 10 homeless people, alleging property violations by the city during sweeps in Golden Gate Park the year before.

Category: Travel
Title: Epcot
Section: Corporate sponsorships

1. Each pavilion was initially sponsored by a corporation which helped fund its construction and maintenance in return for the corporation's logos and some marketing elements appearing throughout the pavilion.
2. For example, Universe of Energy was sponsored by Exxon from 1982 to 2004, and The Land was sponsored by Kraft from 1982 to 1993, then Nestlé from 1993 to 2009.
3. Each pavilion contains a private "VIP area" for its sponsor with offices, lounges, and reception areas hidden away from regular park guests.
4. While some pavilions still retain active sponsorships, in recent years several pavilions have lost sponsorships due to lack of interest from partner companies in renewing expiring agreements.
5. After General Electric left Horizons in 1993, it closed for a couple of years, then reopened temporarily while neighboring attractions Universe of Energy and World of Motion were renovated.
6. Horizons closed permanently on January 9, 1999 and was demolished in the summer of 2000 to make room for the opening of Mission: SPACE on October 9, 2003.
7. Metlife sponsored Wonders of Life from 1989 to 2001, until that area was closed.
8. However, the Wonders Of Life pavilion is still mostly intact and is used for both the Flower and Garden Festival and the Food and Wine Festival.
9. Current active sponsorships include the following:
10. •    Test Track opened in the former World of Motion pavilion and is currently sponsored by Chevrolet
11. •     is currently sponsored by Hewlett-Packard
12. •    Spaceship Earth is currently sponsored by Siemens which also sponsors the park's nighttime show .
13. •    Living with the Land is currently sponsored by Chiquita.
14. •    Individual small attractions and exhibits within the Innoventions pavilions are sponsored by various companies including IBM, Liberty Mutual, Coca-Cola, Velcro, and others.

Category: Travel
Title: Epcot
Section: World Showcase

1. World Showcase is a large area reminiscent of a permanent world's fair containing eleven pavilions, each themed and dedicated to represent a specific country.
2. The eleven pavilions surround the World Showcase Lagoon, a large man-made lake located in the center of World Showcase with a perimeter of 1.2 miles.
3. In clockwise order, the eleven pavilions include:
4. •     Mexico
5. •     Norway
6. •     China
7. •     Germany
8. •     Italy
9. •     United States
10. •     Japan
11. •     Morocco
12. •     France
13. •     United Kingdom
14. •     Canada

15. Of the eleven pavilions, Norway and Morocco were not present at the park's opening, and were added later after park opening.
16. Each pavilion contains themed architecture, landscapes, streetscapes, attractions, shops, and restaurants representing the respective country's culture and cuisine.
17. In an effort to maintain the authenticity of the represented countries, the pavilions are primarily staffed by citizens of the respective countries as part of the Cultural Representative Program through J-1 visa agreements.
18. Some pavilions also contain themed rides, shows, and live entertainment representative of the respective country.
19. The only pavilion that is directly sponsored by the government of its respective country is Morocco, the remaining pavilions are primarily sponsored by private companies with affiliations to the represented countries.
20. Pavilions for Russia, Switzerland, Spain, Venezuela, United Arab Emirates, and Israel have occasionally been rumored as potential future pavilions but have never made it past the planning phases to date.
21. A small African themed refreshment shop known as The Outpost currently resides in the last remaining vacant undeveloped parcel that may potentially one day be developed into a new pavilion area.

Category: Travel
Title: Pike Place Market
Section: Before the Market

1. History.Before the Market.Before the creation of the Pike Place Market in 1907, local Seattle area farmers sold their goods to the public in a three-square block area called The Lots, located at Sixth Avenue and King Street.
2. Most produce sold at The Lots would then be brought to commercial wholesale houses on Western Avenue, which became known as Produce Row.
3. Most farmers, due to the amount of time required to work their farms, were forced to sell their produce on consignment through the wholesalers on Western Avenue.
4. The farmers typically received a percentage of the final sale price for their goods.
5. They would sell to the middleman on commission, as most farmers would often have no time to sell direct to the public, and their earnings would be on marked up prices and expected sales.
6. In some cases, the farmers made a profit, but just as often found themselves breaking even, or getting no money at all due to the business practices of the wholesalers.
7. During the existence of the wholesale houses, which far predated the Market, there were regular rumors as well as instances of corruption in denying payment to farmers.

Category: Travel
Title: Pike Place Market
Section: Victor Steinbrueck Park

1. Victor Steinbrueck Park directly north of the market was originally Market Park.
2. From about 1909 the site held an armory, which was damaged by fire in 1962.
3. The land was taken over by the city in 1968, and the remnant of the armory was razed.
4. In 1970 the land passed to park usage.
5. The resulting Market Park was majorly redesigned in 1982.
6. After Steinbrueck's 1985 death, it was renamed after the architect who was instrumental in the market's preservation.

Category: Travel
Title: Disney's Animal Kingdom
Section: Rafiki's Planet Watch

1. Rafiki's Planet Watch is a section for young children and with families and the only section of the park not connected to Discovery Island, and is instead connected to Africa.
2. Guests board the List of track gauges narrow gauge Wildlife Express Train for the short trip to and from the area, which consists of three sub-areas.
3. Guests first encounter "Habitat Habit!
4. ", where they can see cottontop tamarins and learn about the efforts to protect these endangered primates in their natural homes.
5. Along the way, guests can also learn how to provide animal habitats in and around their own homes.
6. "Conservation Station" showcases the various conservation efforts supported by the Walt Disney Company.
7. It also gives a behind-the-scenes glimpse into Disney's Animal Kingdom's animal care facilities, including a veterinary examination room complete with a two-way communications system so the veterinary staff can answer guest questions.
8. Outside, "Affection Section" is a petting zoo featuring goats, sheep and other domesticated animals.Other animals seen are Ball Pythons, Blue-And-Yellow Macaws, Blue-Tongued Skink, Boa Constrictors, Butterflies, Central Bearded Dragons, Chinchillas, Chinchilla Rabbits, Citron-crested Cockatoos, Common Brushtail Possums, Corn Snakes, Costa Rica Zebra Tarantula, Death's Head Cockroach, Dexter Cattle, Dominique Chickens, Eleonora Cockatoos, Emperor Scorpions, Eclectus Parrots, Fennec Foxes, Ferrets, Giant African Millipedes, Golden Lion Tamarins, Gray Rat Snakes, Green Tree Pythons, Guinea Hogs, Gulf Coast Native Sheep, Hermit Crabs, Hyacinth Macaws, Kinkajous, Llamas, Madagascar Day Geckos, Madagascar Hissing Cockroaches, Madagascar Tree Boas, Nigerian Dwarf Goat, Nile Monitors, North American Donkeys, Opossums, Pygmy Goats, Rats, Rat Snakes, Red-And-Green Macaws, Red-Cockaded Woodpeckers, Red-Crested Turacos, Roughneck Monitor Lizards, San Clemente Island Goats, Savannah Monitors, Solomon Islands Skinks, Spectacled Owls, Striped Skunks, Tamanduas, Tarantulas, Tawny Frogmouths, Tawny Owls, Tenrecs, Tunis Sheep, Two-Toed Sloths, Uromastyx, Variable Hawks, and Vasa Parrots.

Category: Travel
Title: Disney's Animal Kingdom
Section: Avatar: World of Pandora

1. In September 2011, Walt Disney Parks and Resorts announced plans to partner with filmmaker James Cameron, his Lightstorm Entertainment production company, and Fox Filmed Entertainment to develop attractions based on Cameron's "Avatar" film franchise exclusively for Disney theme parks.
2. The first installation is planned for Disney's Animal Kingdom in the form of an "Avatar"-based section of the park.
3. While no specifics were announced, the new area was described as being several acres in size and costing an estimated $400 million to build, a scale similar to Cars Land at Disney California Adventure Park in California.
4. Components from the upcoming second and third films in the "Avatar" series will be featured, along with new designs not seen in any of the films.
5. Construction began on January 10, 2014.

Category: Travel
Title: Disney's Hollywood Studios
Section: Animation Courtyard

1. This section of the park originally was the starting point for the tours of the park's active production studios.
2. Its entrance is marked by a square "studio arch," much like a real Hollywood studio lot entrance might be marked.
3. The Animation Courtyard is home to a number of attractions based on Disney characters.
4. The Magic of Disney Animation is an attraction that examines the development process of an animated character.
5. It also includes interactive games and exhibits, along with meet-and-greet areas for Disney and Pixar characters.When the park first opened in 1989, the "Feature Animation" pavilion of "The Magic of Disney Animation," designed originally by award winning experience designer Bob Rogers (designer) and the design team BRC Imagination Arts, included four connected experiences which explored the legacy of Disney animation.
6. The tour commenced with a short film, entitled "Back to Neverland," in which Veteran newscaster, Walter Cronkite and comedian Robin Williams described the animation process by turning Williams into an animated character in the form of one of the "Lost Boys" of Peter Pan.
7. Following that introductory film, guest would witness the process of animation, first-hand, from elevated, glass-enclosed walkways within one of Disney's actual animation studios, located on the park grounds.
8. The third segment of the animation tour was a short film in which Disney Animators described the joy of the art of animation.
9. A finale film, entitled "Classic Disney" presented a montage of key moments from classic animated Disney films.
10. Mickey Avenue, a sub-section of Animation Courtyard, is home to a walk-through exhibit, , which explores the life and legacy of Walt Disney through photos, models, rare artifacts, and a short biographical film narrated by Julie Andrews.
11. The Legend of Captain Jack Sparrow, is an immersive special effects attraction centered on the adventures of Captain Jack Sparrow from the "Pirates of the Caribbean" series.
12. The Courtyard section also hosts two live shows.
13. "Disney Junior Live on Stage!"
14. entertains guests with puppet characters from the "Disney Junior" block of programming on The Disney Channel, including Mickey Mouse Clubhouse, Doc McStuffins, and Sofia the First.
15. Across the plaza, "Voyage of the Little Mermaid" uses glow-in-the-dark puppets, lasers, music, projectors, human actors and water effects to re-create favorite scenes and songs from the animated "Little Mermaid" film.

Category: Travel
Title: Disney's Hollywood Studios
Section: Annual events

1. Disney's Hollywood Studios hosts a number of events during the year that often draw thousands of fans to the park.
2. •     ESPN The Weekend (late winter) features commentators from the Disney-owned cable sports channels as well as sports celebrities.
3. •     Star Wars Weekends (May - June) brings "Star Wars" fans and celebrities together for special park events.
4. Running Fridays-Sundays throughout June, they feature the 501st Legion (a worldwide "Star Wars" costuming group) parading through the park in Stormtrooper costumes, several "Star Wars" actors appearing each weekend for photos and autographs, Jedi Training Academy classes for younger guests, and other activities.
5. •     The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights (November–January) take over the Streets of America during the Christmas season.
6. The display features over five million Christmas lights on more than of wire.

7. One former event of note was the ABC Super Soap Weekend.
8. Scheduled in November, the event paid tribute to the legions of fans of soap operas from ABC.
9. Guests could meet stars from "All My Children", "One Life to Live" and "General Hospital".
10. The event's final presentation was in November 2008, with ABC instead planning to schedule multiple, smaller regional events around the country for its fans.

Category: Travel
Title: Universal Orlando
Section: Universal Transit

1. Universal Orlando's internal transportation system is often dubbed "Universal Transit."
2. The system consists of water taxis, buses, escalators, elevators, moving walkways, and pathways which transport guests between the parking structure, hotels, CityWalk, the theme parks, and Wet 'n Wild.
3. Onsite hotel guests can get to the theme parks and CityWalk by either boarding a water taxi which will take them directly to CityWalk or may use walkways.
4. The dock at CityWalk is located at the center of CityWalk and can be accessed by theme park visitors via the bridges connecting CityWalk to the theme parks.
5. Along the pathways, bicycles also transport guests for an additional cost.For guests who prefer not to use a water taxi or walk or wish to go to Wet 'n Wild, they will find shuttle transportation also available at the onsite hotels.
6. These stop at five locations: Loews Portofino Bay Hotel & Spa, Hard Rock Hotel, Loews Royal Pacific Resort, Universal Orlando theme parks, and Wet 'n Wild.
7. The resort also features two large parking structures, for day and night guests who need to park, connected by bridge to Citywalk and the theme parks.

Category: Travel
Title: Universal Orlando
Section: Universal's Super Star Shuttle

1. The vicinity of Universal Orlando consists of several hotels and a major airport all located within 20 minutes of the resort.
2. Universal's Super Star Shuttle service is broken into two main routes.
3. One provides transportation to all thirty Universal Partner hotels while the newest route will begin service to Orlando International Airport in late 2012.
4. Universal's Super Star Shuttle also provides transportation between Universal Orlando, SeaWorld, and Wet 'n Wild.
5. The service is free for Universal Parks & Resorts Vacations Guests and onsite hotel guests.
6. The new airport route is expected to initially only be offered for onsite hotel guests.
7. The Super Star Shuttle is run through Mears Transportation.

Category: Travel
Title: Navy Pier
Section: Abstract

1. Navy Pier is a long pier on the Chicago shoreline of Lake Michigan.
2. It is located in the Streeterville neighborhood of the Near North Side community area.
3. The pier was built in 1916 at a cost of $4.5 million.
4. It was a part of the Plan of Chicago developed by architect and city planner Daniel Burnham and his associates.
5. As Municipal Pier #2 (Municipal Pier #1 was never built), Navy Pier was planned and built to serve as a mixed-purpose piece of public infrastructure.
6. Its primary purpose was as a cargo facility for lake freighters, and warehouses were built up and down the Pier.
7. However, the Pier was also designed to provide docking space for passenger excursion steamers, and in the pre–air conditioning era parts of the Pier, especially its outermost tip, were designed to serve as cool places for public gathering and entertainment.
8. The Pier even had its own tram.
9. Today, Navy Pier is Chicago's number one tourist attraction.

Category: Travel
Title: Navy Pier
Section: Third use: college classroom

1. With the war over, Navy Pier went to the University of Illinois, which used the facility beginning in 1946 for a two-year undergraduate program primarily serving returning veterans.
2. From the former Navy staff, Caveny stayed as the Undergraduate Division Dean, and Wolleson as the Dean of Students.
3. During its University of Illinois days, Navy Pier was also the site of a string of public events.
4. The International Exhibitions of the early 1960s drew attractions from around the world, including circus and folkloric dance acts, arts and crafts, and international cuisine.
5. In 1965, the University moved to the Chicago Circle campus, and the Pier again fell into disuse.

Category: Travel
Title: Palace of Versailles
Section: History

1. The earliest mention of the name of Versailles is in a document dated 1038, relating to the village of Versailles.
2. In 1575, the seigneury of Versailles was bought by Albert de Gondi, a naturalized Florentine, who invited Louis XIII on several hunting trips in the forests surrounding Versailles.
3. Pleased with the location, Louis ordered the construction of a hunting lodge in 1624.
4. Eight years later, Louis obtained the seigneury of Versailles from the Gondi family and began to make enlargements to the château.
5. This structure would become the core of the new palace.
6. Louis XIII's successor, Louis XIV, had it expanded into one of the largest palaces in the world.
7. Following the Treaties of Nijmegen in 1678, he began to gradually move the court to Versailles.
8. The court was officially established there on 6 May 1682.After the disgrace of Nicolas Fouquet in 1661, Louis confiscated Fouquet's estate and employed the talents of Le Vau, Le Nôtre, and Le Brun, who all had worked on Fouquet's grand château Vaux-le-Vicomte, for his building campaigns at Versailles and elsewhere.
9. For Versailles, there were four distinct building campaigns.

Category: Travel
Title: Palace of Versailles
Section: Costs of restoration programmes

1. The restoration initiatives launched by the Fifth Republic have proven to be perhaps more costly than the expenditures of the palace in the Ancien Régime.
2. Starting in the 1950s, when the museum of Versailles was under the directorship of Gérald van der Kemp, the objective was to restore the palace to its state – or as close to it as possible – in 1789 when the royal family left the palace.
3. Among the early projects was the repair of the roof over the Hall of Mirrors; the publicity campaign brought international attention to the plight of post-war Versailles and garnered much foreign money including a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.
4. Concurrently, in Russia, the restoration of the Pavlovsk Palace located outside of Leningrad – today's Saint Petersburg – brought the attention of French museum authorities, including the curators of Versailles (Massie, 1990).Pavlovsk Palace was built by Catherine the Great's son Paul.
5. The czarevitch and his wife, Marie Feodorovna, were avid francophiles, who, on a visit to France and Versailles in the 1780s, purchased great quantities of silk, which they later used to upholster furniture in Pavlosk.
6. The palace survived the Russian Revolution intact – descendants of Paul I were living in the palace at the time the communists evicted them – however, during the Second World War, the furniture and artifacts housed in the palace, which had been transformed into a museum, were removed.
7. In the process of evacuation the museum collections, remnants of the silks purchased by Paul I of Russia and Marie Feodorovna were found and conserved.
8. After the war when Soviet authorities were restoring the palace, which had been gutted by the retreating Nazi forces, they recreated the silk fabrics by using the conserved 18th century remnants (Massie, 1990).When the French authorities saw the results of Russian efforts and the high quality they were able to achieve, the French revived 18th-century weaving techniques so as to reproduce the silks used in the decoration of Versailles (Massie, 1990).
9. The two greatest achievements of this initiative are seen today in wall hangings used in the restoration of the "chambre de la reine" in the "grand appartement de reine" and the "chambre du roi" in the "appartement du roi".
10. While the design used for the "chambre du roi" was, in fact, from a design that had been used during the "Ancien Régime" to decorate the "chambre de la reine", it nevertheless represents a great achievement in the on-going restoration at Versailles.
11. Additionally, this project, which took over seven years to achieve, required several hundred kilograms of silver and gold to complete (Meyer, 1989).
12. One of the more costly endeavors for the museum and the government of France's Fifth Republic has been to repurchase as much of the original furnishings as possible.
13. However, because furniture with a royal provenance – and especially furniture that was made for Versailles – is a highly sought after commodity on the international market, the museum has spent considerable funds on retrieving much of the palace's original furnishings (Kemp, 1976).In 2003, a new restoration initiative – the "Grand Versailles" project – was started, which necessitated unexpected repair and replantation of the gardens.
14. The project will be on-going for the next seventeen years, funded with a state endowment of €135 million allocated for the first seven years.
15. The project will address such concerns as security for the palace, and continued restoration of the "bosquet des trois fontaines".
16. VINCI underwrote the €12 million restoration project for the Hall of Mirrors, which was completed in 2006 (Leloup, 2006).We may never know the true amount spent on the creation of Versailles, and most current estimates are speculative.
17. A recent estimate has placed the amount spent on Versailles during the "Ancien régime" as US$2 billion (Littell, 2000).
18. This figure in all probability is an under-evaluation of the money spent on Versailles.
19. France's Fifth Republic expenditures alone that have been directed to restoration and maintenance at Versailles undoubtedly surpass those of the Sun King.

Category: Travel
Title: Universal Studios Hollywood
Section: Attraction history

1. In 1965, The War Lord Tower opened as one of the first attractions in the theme park.
2. This was followed by the opening of the Animal Actors School Stage in 1970.
3. In 1974, the Rockslide staged event was added to the Studio Tour.
4. The following year The Land of a Thousand Faces opened on the Upper Lot.
5. In 1979, The Battle of Galactica replaced Rockslide as a staged event on the Studio Tour.The Flintstones Show opened, replacing the Star Trek Adventure.
6. In 1996, opened.
7. In 1997, two shows were replaced: The Land Before Time show replaced Rocky and Bullwinkle Live; and Totally Nickelodeon replaced The Flintstones Show.
8. Just one year after it opened, The Land Before Time show was replaced with Coke Soak.
9. In 1999, T2 3-D: Battle Across Time and a Chicken Run Walkthrough opened on the upper lot.
10. Additionally, Beetlejuice's Rock and Roll Graveyard Revue was closed.In 2000, the Rugrats Magic Adventure replaced Totally Nickelodeon.
11. In 2001, the Nickelodeon Blast Zone opened.
12. Also in 2001, Animal Planet Live replaced the Animal Actors School Stage.
13. In 2 replaced The Mummy Returns: Chamber of Doom.
14. The following year, Fear Factor Live replaced Spider-Man Rocks.
15. In 2007, Universal's House of Horrors opened, replacing Van Helsing: Fortress Dracula.
16. Both Lucy: A Tribute and Back to the Future: The Ride were closed, prior to being replaced in 2008 by The Simpsons Ride and The Universal Story Museum respectively.
17. Also in 2008, the Nickelodeon Blast Zone was rebranded to The Adventures of Curious George.
18. In 2009, Creature from the Black Lagoon: The Musical replaced Fear Factor Live in the Upper Lot.In 2010, the Special Effects Stages and Backdraft attractions were closed to make way for Transformers: The Ride which was announced in 2008 (Special Effects Stages was moved to the former Creature From The Black Lagoon building and reopened as Special Effects Stage).
19. King Kong 360 3-D also opened.
20. On May 24, 2012, Transformers: The Ride opened on the Lower Lot.
21. On December 31, 2012, Universal Studios Hollywood closed for , the attraction at Universal Studios Florida, set to come in the April of 2014.Universal Studios Hollywood has plans to open The Wizarding World of Harry Potter which will feature the Harry Potter and the Forbidden Journey ride sometime in 2015-2016.

Category: Travel
Title: Universal Studios Hollywood
Section: Upper lot

1. The Upper lot is home to a variety of family based shows.
2. It is also home to many dining and merchandise shops as well as the park's entrance.
3. For older guests the park offers "Universal's House of Horrors", a year-round haunted house.
4. The Upper lot is home to all of the park's 5 shows including "The Blues Brothers Revue", the "Universal's Animal Actors Show", the "Special Effects Stage", "" and "Shrek 4-D", a 3-D film which features additional immerse features.
5. There are 2 rides located on the upper lot which include: the "Studio Tour" and the "The Simpsons Ride" are offered.
6. The "Studio Tour" is a 45 minute ride which uses tram vehicles to take the visitors to the theme park's back-lot.
7. The tour is the signature ride at the theme park and the wait time varies by day and seasons.
8. The wait time ranges from 5–80 minutes, depending on the amount of visitors.
9. The tour includes:, the world's largest 3-D experience.
10. The tram closes earlier than other shows and rides at the park.
11. The trams depart the station and pass directly under the "Starway".
12. After passing the starway, the tram arrives at the lower lot and passes through the stages where film productions take place.
13. When filming occurs, the ride operator will notify visitors.
14. The tram then takes the guests to Courthouse Square section and then other buildings in the backlot.
15. Afterwards, the tram enters a tunnel leading to the attraction: King Kong 360 3D.
16. After King Kong 360 3D, the tram travels through sets from Jurassic park and encounter Dilophosauruses.
17. Following that, the tram travels to the Flash Flood attraction (it is to be noted guests on the left side of the tram usually get wet).
18. The tram continues to attraction, and Bates motel from Psycho.
19. The Simpsons Ride is a family simulator ride located next to the entrance to the Studio Tour ride.
20. The ride contains 24 vehicles, where each vehicles seats 8 guests.
21. The ride lasts for 4 minutes.
22. None of the rides at the Upper lot have single rider lines.There are several themed retail outlets located near their respective rides in the Upper lot.
23. For the Simpsons merchandise is offered at the Kwik-E-Mart.

Category: Travel
Title: Bourbon Street
Section: Issues

1. Historically noise violations were the responsibility of the party making the noise.
2. This changed in 1996 with "Yokum v. 615 Bourbon Street".
3. The case ruled that the property owner, not the noise-maker is responsible for noise violations.
4. A 2010 city ordinance stipulates that no music may be played in the French Quarter between 8 pm and 9 am.
5. Enforcement has been inconsistent and critics claim its goals are vague.
6. Some even state that is unconstitutional.
7. Besides being difficult to enforce, music aficionados claim that noise ordinances threaten the city's music culture.
8. Local jazz bands, such as the To Be Continued Brass Band, who play in the streets would be prohibited from doing so under such ordinances.Aggressive solicitation bans are a newer issue on Bourbon Street.
9. In 2011, an ordinance was passed that banned individuals and groups from "disseminating any social, political or religious message" at night.
10. The ordinance does not explain the justification for this ban.
11. On September 21, 2012, the ACLU of Louisiana won a temporary restraining order against the ban on behalf of Kelsey McCauley, a woman who converted to Christianity through a religious group's activities on Bourbon Street which had several of its members arrested, and some of which were cited, on September 14, 2012 for violating the ordinance.
12. A hearing was set for October 1, 2012.On July 25, 2013, the New Orleans City Council voted 6-0 to amend the law to remove the Bourbon Street ban, with language that was acceptable to attorneys on all opposing sides.

Category: Travel
Title: Lincoln Memorial
Section: Interior

1. The area where the statue stands is 60 feet wide, 74 feet long, and 60 feet high.
2. The interior of the Memorial is divided into three chambers by two rows of Ionic columns.
3. These columns, four in each row, are tall and in diameter at their base.
4. The north and south side chambers contain carved inscriptions of Lincoln's second inaugural address and his Gettysburg Address.
5. Bordering these inscriptions are pilasters ornamented with fasces, eagles, and wreaths.
6. The inscriptions and adjoining ornamentation were done by Evelyn Beatrice Longman.The Memorial is filled with symbolism: the 36 columns represent the states in the union at the time of Lincoln's death, the 48 stone festoons on the attic above the columns represent the 48 states in 1922.
7. Above each of the inscriptions is a mural painted by Jules Guerin graphically portraying governing principles evident in Lincoln's life.
8. On the south wall mural, Freedom, Liberty, Immortality, Justice, and the Law are pictured, while the north wall portrays Unity, Fraternity, and Charity.
9. Both scenes contain a background of cypress trees, the emblem of Eternity.
10. The murals were crafted with a special mixture of paint which included elements of kerosene and wax to protect the exposed artwork from fluctuations in temperature and moisture conditions.The ceiling of the Memorial, above the floor, is composed of bronze girders, ornamented with laurel and oak leaves.
11. Between the girders are panels of Alabama marble, saturated with paraffin to increase their translucency.
12. Despite the increased light from this device, Bacon and French felt the statue required even more light.
13. They decided upon an artificial lighting system in which a louvered lighting panel would be set in the ceiling with metal slats to conceal the great floodlights.
14. Custodians could adjust the lights from a control room, varying them according to the outside light.
15. Funds for this expensive system were appropriated by Congress in 1926, and in 1929, seven years after the dedication, the statue was properly lighted.
16. Since that time, only one major alteration has taken place in the Memorial's design.
17. This was the addition of an elevator within the structure to aid handicapped visitors, which was installed in the mid-1970s.

Category: Travel
Title: Lincoln Memorial
Section: Statue

1. Lying between the north and south chambers is the central hall containing the solitary figure of Lincoln sitting in contemplation.
2. The statue was carved by the Piccirilli Brothers under the supervision of the sculptor, Daniel Chester French, and took four years to complete.
3. The statue, originally intended to be only tall, was, on further consideration, enlarged so that it finally stood tall from head to foot, the scale being such that if Lincoln were standing, he would be tall.
4. The extreme width of the statue is the same as its height.
5. The Georgia white marble sculpture weighs and had to be shipped in 28 separate pieces.The statue rests upon an oblong pedestal of Tennessee marble high, wide, and deep.
6. Directly beneath this lies a platform of Tennessee marble about long, wide, and high.
7. Lincoln's arms rest on representations of Roman fasces, a subtle touch that associates the statue with the Augustan (and imperial) theme (obelisk and funerary monuments) of the Washington Mall.
8. The statue is discretely bordered by two pilasters, one on each side.
9. Between these pilasters and above Lincoln's head stands the engraved epitaph, composed by Royal Cortissoz, shown in the box to the left.

Category: Travel
Title: Metropolitan Museum of Art
Section: Drawings and prints

1. Though other departments contain significant numbers of drawings and prints, the Drawings and Prints department specifically concentrates on North American pieces and western European works produced after the Middle Ages.
2. The first Old Master drawings, comprising 670 sheets, were presented as a single group in 1880 by Cornelius Vanderbilt II and in effect launched the department, though it was not formally constituted as a department until later.
3. Other early donors to the department include Junius Spencer Morgan II who presented a broad range of material, but mainly dated from the sixteenth century, including 2 woodblocks and many prints by Albrecht Dürer in 1919.
4. Currently, the Drawings and Prints collection contains more than 17,000 drawings, 1.5 million prints, and twelve thousand illustrated books.
5. The great masters of European painting, who produced many more sketches and drawings than actual paintings, are extensively represented in the Drawing and Prints collection.
6. The department's holdings contain major drawings by Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, and Rembrandt, as well as prints and etchings by Van Dyck, Dürer, and Degas among many others.

Category: Travel
Title: Metropolitan Museum of Art
Section: Robert Lehman Collection

1. On the passing of banker Robert Lehman in 1969, his Foundation donated 2,600 works of art to the museum.
2. Housed in the "Robert Lehman Wing," the museum refers to the collection as "one of the most extraordinary private art collections ever assembled in the United States".
3. To emphasize the personal nature of the Robert Lehman Collection, the Met housed the collection in a special set of galleries which evoked the interior of Lehman's richly decorated townhouse; this intentional separation of the Collection as a "museum within the museum" met with mixed criticism and approval at the time, though the acquisition of the collection was seen as a coup for the Met.
4. Unlike other departments at the Met, the Robert Lehman collection does not concentrate on a specific style or period of art; rather, it reflects Lehman's personal interests.
5. Lehman the collector concentrated heavily on paintings of the Italian Renaissance, particularly the Sienese school.
6. Paintings in the collection include masterpieces by Botticelli and Domenico Veneziano, as well as works by a significant number of Spanish painters, El Greco and Goya among them.
7. Lehman's collection of drawings by the Old Masters, featuring works by Rembrandt and Dürer, is particularly valuable for its breadth and quality.
8. Princeton University Press has documented the massive collection in a multi-volume book series published as "The Robert Lehman Collection Catalogues".

Category: Travel
Title: Universal Studios Florida
Section: New York

1. This section of the park is aptly named.
2. Within its boundaries can be found architectural styles and sets that resemble the New York from the past and present.
3. New York's flagship attraction is Revenge of the Mummy: The Ride.
4. Opening in May 2004, this indoor roller coaster was inspired by "The Mummy film franchise".
5. Outside the ride guests can purchase merchandise items from "Sahara Traders".
6. Twister...Ride it Out is a live-action attraction that uses special effects to simulate a tornado.
7. It was inspired by the 1996 film "Twister".
8. The attraction opened in 1998 and features a merchandise shop entitled "Aftermath" nearby.A walkthrough attraction named Delancey Street Preview Center allows visitors to preview upcoming films or television shows created by Universal Studios.
9. This allows the company to receive feedback from a wide range of sources.
10. The Preview Center opened in 2006.
11. In the streets of New York, The Blues Brothers perform a variety of classic rock and soul songs multiple times per day in The Blues Brothers Live.New York features several dining outlets: "Finnegan's Bar and Grill" and "Louie's Italian Restaurant" which were designed for the park as well as "Starbucks Coffee" and "Ben & Jerry's" which are commercial franchises.
12. Within New York exist three merchandise shops: "Sahara Traders", "Aftermath" and "Rosie's Irish Shop".
13. The first two feature merchandise related to attractions within this area.As Nickelodeon was headquartered in the park at the time, the opening credits for "Roundhouse" and "All That" (two of its shows) were filmed around this area of the park.

Category: Travel
Title: Universal Studios Florida
Section: Hollywood

1. The Hollywood section of the park greets guests with recreations of some of Hollywood's greatest monuments, such as Schwab's Drug Store and Mel's Drive-In.
2. These recreations are accompanied by two shows and a walkthrough exhibit.
3. Hollywood is also home to the world famous state of the art Radio Broadcast Center.
4. The studios are on the corner between Schwab's and The Brown Derby.
5. The Radio Broadcast Center hosts radio stations from all over the world.Lucy: A Tribute is a walk-through museum featuring the best of "America's favorite redhead", Lucille Ball.
6. "Universal's Horror Make-Up Show" is a live stage show that shows guests how horror film special effects are created.
7. Before the main show guests experience a pre-show walk-through of set pieces and props used in various horror movies.
8. The pre-show currently houses a character appearance by Hellboy from "".
9. In August 2008, a section of the pre-show lobby was included to contain material from Halloween Horror Nights which includes some concept art, and a timeline of park map covers dating from its debut year in 1991 as Fright Nights.
10. Both of these attractions opened in 1990.
11. The final attraction is .
12. The show is a live, 3D experience that combines a 3-D film with an actual stage show based on the film "Terminator 2".Hollywood's two dining outlets are recreations of actual Hollywood outlets.
13. "Schwab's Pharmacy" and "Mel's Drive-In" offer guests a variety of food and beverage options.
14. A third outlet, named "Cafe La Bamba", operates seasonally.
15. Guests can purchase Terminator merchandise from "Cyber Image" and magic-related items from "Theatre Magic".

Category: Travel
Title: British Museum
Section: Collecting from the wider world (1850–75)

1. Collecting from the wider world (1850–75).The opening of the forecourt in 1852 marked the completion of Robert Smirke's 1823 plan, but already adjustments were having to be made to cope with the unforeseen growth of the collections.
2. Infill galleries were constructed for Assyrian sculptures and Sydney Smirke's Round Reading Room, with space for a million books, opened in 1857.
3. Because of continued pressure on space the decision was taken to move natural history to a new building in South Kensington, which would later become the British Museum of Natural History.Roughly contemporary with the construction of the new building was the career of a man sometimes called the "second founder" of the British Museum, the Italian librarian Anthony Panizzi.
4. Under his supervision, the British Museum Library (now the British Library) quintupled in size and became a well-organised institution worthy of being called a national library, the largest library in the world after the National Library of Paris.
5. The quadrangle at the centre of Smirke's design proved to be a waste of valuable space and was filled at Panizzi's request by a circular Reading Room of cast iron, designed by Smirke's brother, Sydney Smirke.Until the mid-19th century, the Museum's collections were relatively circumscribed but, in 1851, with the appointment to the staff of Augustus Wollaston Franks to curate the collections, the Museum began for the first time to collect British and European medieval antiquities, prehistory, branching out into Asia and diversifying its holdings of ethnography.
6. Overseas excavations continued and John Turtle Wood discovered the remains of the 4th century BC Temple of Artemis at Ephesos, another Wonder of the Ancient World.

Category: Travel
Title: British Museum
Section: Scholarship and legacies (1875–1900)

1. Scholarship and legacies (1875–1900).The natural history collections were an integral part of the British Museum until their removal to the new British Museum of Natural History, now the Natural History Museum, in 1887.
2. With the departure and the completion of the new White Wing (fronting Montague Street) in 1884, more space was available for antiquities and ethnography and the library could further expand.
3. This was a time of innovation as electric lighting was introduced in the Reading Room and exhibition galleries.In 1882 the Museum was involved in the establishment of the independent Egypt Exploration Fund (now Society) the first British body to carry out research in Egypt.
4. A bequest from Miss Emma Turner in 1892 financed excavations in Cyprus.
5. In 1897 the death of the great collector and curator, A.W.
6. Franks, was followed by an immense bequest of 3,300 finger rings, 153 drinking vessels, 512 pieces of continental porcelain, 1,500 netsuke, 850 inro, over 30,000 bookplates and miscellaneous items of jewellery and plate, among them the Oxus Treasure.In 1898 Baron Ferdinand de Rothschild bequeathed the glittering contents from his New Smoking Room at Waddesdon Manor as the Waddesdon Bequest.
7. This consisted of almost 300 pieces of "objets d'art et de vertu" which included exquisite examples of jewellery, plate, enamel, carvings, glass and maiolica, among them the Holy Thorn Reliquary, probably created in the 1390s in Paris for John, Duke of Berry.
8. The collection was in the tradition of a schatzkammer or treasure house such as those formed by the Renaissance princes of Europe.
9. Baron Ferdinand's will was most specific, and failure to observe the terms would make it void, the collection should be

Category: Travel
Title: National Air and Space Museum
Section: Abstract

1. The National Air and Space Museum (NASM) of the Smithsonian Institution holds the largest collection of historic aircraft and spacecraft in the world in of exhibition floor space.
2. It was established in 1946, as the National Air Museum and opened its main building in 1976.
3. Located in Washington, D.C., United States, it is a center for research into the history and science of aviation and spaceflight, as well as planetary science and terrestrial geology and geophysics.
4. Almost all space and aircraft on display are originals or backups to the originals.
5. It operates an annex, the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center, at Dulles International Airport, which opened in 2003 and itself encompasses .
6. The museum currently conducts restoration of its collection at the Paul E. Garber Preservation, Restoration, and Storage Facility in Suitland, Maryland.

Category: Travel
Title: National Air and Space Museum
Section: History

1. The museum was originally called the National Air Museum when formed on August 12, 1946 by an act of Congress and signed into law by President Harry S. Truman.
2. Some pieces in the National Air and Space Museum collection date back to the 1876 Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia after which the Chinese Imperial Commission donated a group of kites to the Smithsonian after Smithsonian Secretary Spencer Fullerton Baird convinced exhibiters that shipping them home would be too costly.
3. The Stringfellow steam engine intended for aircraft was added to the collection in 1889, the first piece actively acquired by the Smithsonian now in the current NASM collection.After the establishment of the museum, there was no one building that could hold all the items to be displayed, many obtained from the United States Army and United States Navy collections of domestic and captured aircraft from World War I.
4. Some pieces were on display in the Arts and Industries Building, some were stored in the Aircraft Building (also known as the "Tin Shed"), a large temporary metal shed in the Smithsonian Castle's south yard.
5. Larger missiles and rockets were displayed outdoors in what was known as Rocket Row.
6. The shed housed at large Martin bomber, a LePere fighter-bomber, and an Aeromarine 39B floatplane.
7. Still, much of the collection remained in storage due to a lack of display space.The combination of the large numbers of aircraft donated to the Smithsonian after World War II and the need for hangar and factory space for the Korean War drove the Smithsonian to look for its own facility to store and restore aircraft.
8. The current Garber Facility was ceded to the Smithsonian by the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission in 1952 after the curator Paul E. Garber spotted the wooded area from the air.
9. Bulldozers from Fort Belvoir and prefabricated buildings from the United States Navy kept the initial costs low.The space race in the 1950s and 1960s led to the renaming of the museum to the National Air and Space Museum, and finally congressional passage of appropriations for the construction of the new exhibition hall, which opened July 1, 1976 at the height of the United States Bicentennial festivities under the leadership of Director Michael Collins, who had flown to the Moon on Apollo 11.
10. The Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center opened in 2003, funded by a private donation.The museum received COSTAR, the corrective optics instrument installed in the Hubble Space Telescope during its first servicing mission (STS-61), when it was removed and returned to Earth after Space Shuttle mission STS-125.
11. The museum also holds the backup mirror for the Hubble which, unlike the one that was launched, was ground to the correct shape.
12. There were once plans for it to be installed to the Hubble itself, but plans to return the satellite to Earth were scrapped after the Space Shuttle "Columbia" disaster in 2003; the mission was re-considered as too risky.The Smithsonian has also been promised the International Cometary Explorer, which is currently in a solar orbit that occasionally brings it back to Earth, should NASA attempt to recover it.

Category: Travel
Title: Victoria Peak
Section: History

1. As early as 19th century, the Peak attracted prominent European residents because of its panoramic view over the city and its temperate climate compared to the sub-tropical climate in the rest of Hong Kong.
2. The sixth Governor of Hong Kong, Sir Richard MacDonnell had a summer residence built on the Peak circa 1868.
3. Those that built houses named them whimsically, such as The Eyrie, and the Austin Arms.
4. See First houses on the Peak.These original residents reached their homes by sedan chairs, which were carried up and down the steep slope of Victoria Peak.
5. This limited development of the Peak until the opening of the Peak Tram funicular in 1888.The boost to accessibility caused by the opening of the Peak Tram created demand for residences on the Peak.
6. Between 1904 and 1930, the Peak Reservation Ordinance designated the Peak as an exclusive residential area reserved for non-Chinese.
7. They also reserved the Peak Tram for the use of such passengers during peak periods.
8. The Peak remains an upmarket residential area, although residency today is based on wealth.

Category: Travel
Title: Victoria Peak
Section: Tourism

1. With some seven million visitors every year, the Peak is a major tourist attraction of Hong Kong.
2. It offers spectacular views of the city and its harbours.
3. The viewing deck also has coin operated telescopes that the visitors can use to enjoy the cityscape.
4. The number of visitors led to the construction of two major leisure and shopping centres, the Peak Tower and the Peak Galleria, situated adjacent to each other.
5. The Peak Tower incorporates the upper station of the Peak Tram, the funicular railway that brings passengers up from the St. John's Cathedral in Hong Kong's Central district, whilst the Peak Galleria incorporates the bus station used by the Hong Kong public buses and green minibuses on the Peak.
6. The Peak is also accessible by taxi and private car via the circuitous Peak Road, or by walking up the steep Old Peak Road from near the Zoological Botanical Gardens.Victoria Peak Garden is located on the site of Mountain Lodge, the Governor's old summer residence, and is the closest publicly accessible point to the summit.
7. It can be reached from Victoria Gap by walking up Mount Austin Road, a climb of about .
8. Another popular walk is the level loop along Lugard Road, giving good views of Hong Kong's Central district and Kowloon, and then returning via Harlech Road, encircling the summit at the level of the Peak Tower.There are several restaurants on Victoria Peak, most of which are located in the two shopping centres.
9. However, the Peak Lookout Restaurant, is housed in an older and more traditional building which was originally a spacious house for engineers working on the Peak Tramway.
10. It was rebuilt in 1901 as a stop area for sedan chairs, but was re-opened as a restaurant in 1947.In addition to being a major tourist attraction for Hong Kong, The Peak is also the summit of Hong Kong's property market.
11. At the peak of The Peak, properties are more precious than anywhere else in the world.Most of the super rich in Hong Kong - including Cheung Kong (Holdings) chairman Li Ka-shing and the Kwok brothers of Sun Hung Kai Properties - live in detached houses in Island South or The Peak.A house at Barker Road (where Hong Kong's most expensive residential buildings are located) sold for HK$1.8 billion last year.
12. At $68,228 per square foot, it is the most expensive location in the world.
13. The buyer is reported to be a Hong Kong billionaire, Lee Shau-kee.On January 12.
14. 2014, a Barker Road property sold at over HK$100k (US$13k) per square foot for HK$690 million.

Category: Travel
Title: Disney California Adventure
Section: Early changes and expansions

1. Two of the park's major criticisms in its first year were the lack of attractions appealing to children and the lack of a show or parade at night to keep visitors from leaving at nightfall.
2. Within the first year of operation, Disney's Electrical Parade and Who Wants to Be a Millionaire – Play It!
3. were brought to the park, and several of its original rides and attractions were closed, including Superstar Limo and "Disney's Steps in Time".
4. Attractions for children were immediately added including A Bug's Land, The Twilight Zone Tower of Terror, and more costumed characters around the park.
5. Monsters, Inc. Mike & Sulley to the Rescue!
6. opened in the former Superstar Limo building in January 2006.

Category: Travel
Title: Disney California Adventure
Section: Grizzly Peak

1. Grizzly Peak is themed around California's wilderness and national parks with particular references to Yosemite and Redwood national parks.
2. Its main attraction is Grizzly River Run, a Gold Rush-esque river rapids ride around the summit of Grizzly Peak.
3. Nearby is the Redwood Creek Challenge Trail; a playground area that includes a show featuring characters from Disney·Pixar's "Up".
4. A special entrance exclusive to guests of Disney's Grand Californian Hotel is located in this area.
5. There are also several restaurants in the Grizzly Peak district that are themed to California's farmland and heritage.
6. California-themed food and wine festivals are hosted in this area as well.

Category: Travel
Title: Sydney Opera House
Section: Abstract

1. The Sydney Opera House is a multi-venue performing arts centre in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia.
2. Situated on Bennelong Point in Sydney Harbour, close to the Sydney Harbour Bridge, the facility is adjacent to the Sydney central business district and the Royal Botanic Gardens, between Sydney and Farm Coves.Designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon, the facility formally opened on 20 October 1973 after a gestation beginning with Utzon's 1957 selection as winner of an international design competition.
3. The NSW Government, led by Premier Joseph Cahill, authorised work to begin in 1958, with Utzon directing construction.
4. The government's decision to build Utzon's design is often overshadowed by circumstances that followed, including cost and scheduling overruns as well as the architect's ultimate resignation.Though its name suggests a single venue, the project comprises multiple performance venues which together are among the busiest performing arts centres in the world — hosting over 1,500 performances each year attended by some 1.2 million people.
5. The venues produce and present a wide range of in-house productions and accommodate numerous performing arts companies, including four key resident companies: Opera Australia, The Australian Ballet, the Sydney Theatre Company and the Sydney Symphony Orchestra.
6. As one of the most popular visitor attractions in Australia, more than seven million people visit the site each year, with 300,000 people participating annually in a guided tour of the facility.Identified as one of the 20th century's most distinctive buildings and one of the most famous performing arts centres in the world, the facility is managed by the Sydney Opera House Trust, under the auspices of the New South Wales Ministry of the Arts.The Sydney Opera House became a UNESCO World Heritage Site on 28 June 2007.

Category: Travel
Title: Sydney Opera House
Section: Opening

1. The Opera House was formally opened by Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, on 20 October 1973.
2. A large crowd attended.
3. Utzon was not invited to the ceremony, nor was his name mentioned.
4. The opening was televised and included fireworks and a performance of Beethoven's Symphony No.
5. 9.

Category: Travel
Title: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
Section: Abstract

1. Great Smoky Mountains National Park is a United States National Park and UNESCO World Heritage Site that straddles the ridgeline of the Great Smoky Mountains, part of the Blue Ridge Mountains, which are a division of the larger Appalachian Mountain chain.
2. The border between Tennessee and North Carolina runs northeast to southwest through the centerline of the park.
3. It is the most visited national park in the United States.
4. On its route from Maine to Georgia, the Appalachian Trail also passes through the center of the park.
5. The park was chartered by the United States Congress in 1934 and officially dedicated by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt in 1940.
6. It encompasses , making it one of the largest protected areas in the eastern United States.
7. The main park entrances are located along U.S. Highway 441 (Newfound Gap Road) at the towns of Gatlinburg, Tennessee, and Cherokee, North Carolina.
8. It was the first national park whose land and other costs were paid for in part with federal funds; previous parks were funded wholly with state money or private funds.

Category: Travel
Title: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
Section: Natural features

1. Elevations in the park range from at the mouth of Abrams Creek to at the summit of Clingmans Dome.
2. Within the park a total of sixteen mountains reach higher than 6,000 feet (1829 m).The wide range of elevations mimics the latitudinal changes found throughout the entire eastern United States.
3. Indeed, ascending the mountains is comparable to a trip from Tennessee to Canada.
4. Plants and animals common in the country's Northeast have found suitable ecological niches in the park's higher elevations, while southern species find homes in the balmier lower reaches.During the most recent ice age, the northeast-to-southwest orientation of the Appalachian mountains allowed species to migrate southward along the slopes rather than finding the mountains to be a barrier.
5. As climate warms, many northern species are now retreating upward along the slopes and withdrawing northward, while southern species are expanding.The park normally has very high humidity and precipitation, averaging from 55 inches (1,400 mm) per year in the valleys to 85 inches (2,200 mm) per year on the peaks.
6. This is more annual rainfall than anywhere in the United States outside the Pacific Northwest and parts of Alaska and Hawaii.
7. It is also generally cooler than the lower elevations below, and most of the park has a humid continental climate more comparable to locations much farther north, as opposed to the humid subtropical climate in the lowlands.
8. The park is almost 95 percent forested, and almost 36 percent of it, , is estimated by the Park Service to be old growth forest with many trees that predate European settlement of the area.
9. It is one of the largest blocks of deciduous, temperate, old growth forest in North America.The variety of elevations, the abundant rainfall, and the presence of old growth forests give the park an unusual richness of biota.
10. About 10,000 species of plants and animals are known to live in the park, and estimates as high as an additional 90,000 undocumented species may also be present.Park officials count more than 200 species of birds, 66 species of mammals, 50 species of fish, 39 species of reptiles, and 43 species of amphibians, including many lungless salamanders.
11. The park has a noteworthy black bear population, numbering about 1,500.
12. An experimental re-introduction of elk (wapiti) into the park began in 2001.Over 100 species of trees grow in the park.
13. The lower region forests are dominated by deciduous leafy trees.
14. At higher altitudes, deciduous forests give way to coniferous trees like Fraser Fir.
15. In addition, the park has over 1,400 flowering plant species and over 4,000 species of non-flowering plants.

Category: Art
Title: Vitruvian Man
Section: Abstract

1. The Vitruvian Man, , is a drawing created by Leonardo da Vinci circa 1490.
2. It is accompanied by notes based on the work of the architect Vitruvius.
3. The drawing, which is in pen and ink on paper, depicts a male figure in two superimposed positions with his arms and legs apart and simultaneously inscribed in a circle and square.
4. The drawing and text are sometimes called the "Canon of Proportions" or, less often, "Proportions of Man".
5. It is kept in the Gabinetto dei disegni e stampe of the Gallerie dell'Accademia, in Venice, Italy, under reference 228.
6. Like most works on paper, it is displayed to the public only occasionally.The drawing is based on the correlations of ideal human proportions with geometry described by the ancient Roman architect Vitruvius in Book III of his treatise "De Architectura".
7. Vitruvius described the human figure as being the principal source of proportion among the Classical orders of architecture.
8. Vitruvius determined that the ideal body should be eight heads high.
9. Leonardo's drawing is traditionally named in honor of the architect.

Category: Art
Title: Vitruvian Man
