5. Certain countries around the world rely heavily on bicycles and their culture has developed around the bicycle as a primary form of transport.
6. In Europe Belgium and Holland are two of the biggest advocates and users of bicycles as a method of day to day transportation.
7. Road bikes tend to have a more upright shape and a shorter wheelbase, which make the bike more mobile but harder to ride slowly.
8. The design, coupled with low or dropped handlebars, requires the rider to bend forward more, utilizing stronger muscles (particularly the gluteus maximus) and reducing air resistance at high speed.The price of a new bicycle can range from US$50 to more than US$20,000 (the highest priced bike in the world is the custom Madone by Damien Hirst, sold at $500,000 USD), depending on quality, type and weight (the most exotic road bicycles can weigh as little as 3.2 kg (7 lb)).
9. However, UCI regulations stipulates a legal race bike cannot weigh less than 6.8 kg (14.99 lbs).
10. Being measured for a bike and taking it for a test ride are recommended before buying.The drivetrain components of the bike should also be considered.
11. A middle grade dérailleur is sufficient for a beginner, although many utility bikes come equipped with hub gears.
12. If the rider plans a significant amount of hillclimbing, a triple-crank (three chainrings) front gear system may be preferred.
13. Otherwise, the relatively lighter and less expensive two chainrings may be better.
14. Much simpler fixed wheel bikes are also available.Many road bikes along with mountain bikes include clipless pedals to which special shoes attach, via a cleat, permitting the rider to pull on the pedals as well as push.
15. Other possible accessories for the bicycle include front and rear lights, bells or horns, child carrying seats, cycling computers with GPS, locks, bar tape, fenders (mud-guards), baggage racks, baggage carriers and pannier bags, water bottles and bottle cages.For basic maintenance and repairs, cyclists can choose to carry a pump (or a CO2 cartridge), a puncture repair kit, a spare inner tube, and tire levers.
16. Cycling can be more efficient and comfortable with special shoes, gloves, and shorts.
17. In wet weather, riding can be more tolerable with waterproof clothes, such as cape, jacket, trousers (pants) and overshoes.Items legally required in some jurisdictions, or voluntarily adopted for safety reasons, include bicycle helmets, generator or battery operated lights, reflectors, and audible signalling devices such as a bell or horn.
18. Extras include studded tires and a bicycle computer.Bikes can also be heavily customized, with different seat designs and handle bars, for example.

Category: Sport
Title: Cycling
Section: Bicycle Touring

1. Recreational.Bicycle Touring.Bicycles are used for recreation at all ages.
2. Bicycle touring, also known as cyclotourism, involves touring and exploration or sightseeing by bicycle for leisure.
3. A brevet or randonnée is an organized long-distance ride.One popular Dutch pleasure is the enjoyment of relaxed cycling in the countryside of the Netherlands.
4. The land is very flat and full of public bicycle trails where cyclists are not bothered by cars and other traffic, which makes it ideal for cycling recreation.
5. Many Dutch people subscribe every year to an event called "fietsvierdaagse" — four days of organised cycling through the local environment.
6. Paris–Brest–Paris (PBP), which began in 1891, is the oldest bicycling event still run on a regular basis on the open road, covers over and imposes a 90-hour time limit.
7. Similar if smaller institutions exist in many countries.

Category: Sport
Title: Diving
Section: Synchronized diving

1. Synchronized diving was adopted as an Olympic sport in 2000.
2. Two divers form a team and perform dives simultaneously.
3. The dives are identical.
4. It used to be possible to dive opposites, also known as a pinwheel, but this is no longer part of competitive synchronized diving.
5. For example, one diver would perform a forward dive and the other an inward dive in the same position, or one would do a reverse and the other a back movement.
6. In these events, the diving would be judged both on the quality of execution and the synchronicity – in timing of take-off and entry, height and forward travel.

Category: Sport
Title: Diving
Section: Canada

1. Most provincial level competitions consist of events for 6 age groups (Groups A, B, C, D, E, and Open) for both genders on each of the three board levels.
2. These age groups roughly correspond to those standardized by FINA, with the addition of a youngest age group for divers 9 and younger, Group E, which does not compete nationally and does not have a tower event (although divers of this age may choose to compete in Group D).
3. The age group Open is so called because divers of any age, including those over 18, may compete in these events, so long as their dives meet a minimum standard of difficulty.Although Canada is internationally a fairly strong country in diving, the vast majority of Canadian high schools and universities do not have diving teams, and many Canadian divers accept athletic scholarships from American colleges.Adult divers who are not competitive at an elite level may compete in masters diving.
4. Typically, masters are either adults who never practiced the sport as children or teenagers, or former elite athletes who have retired but still seek a way to be involved in the sport.
5. Many diving clubs have masters teams in addition to their primary competitive ones, and while some masters dive only for fun and fitness, there are also masters competitions, which range from the local to world championship level.

Category: Sport
Title: Field hockey
Section: Free hits

1. Free hits are awarded when offences are committed outside the scoring circles (the term 'free hit' is standard usage but the ball need not be hit).
2. The ball may be hit, pushed or lifted in any direction by the team offended against.
3. The ball can be lifted from a free hit but not by hitting, you must flick or scoop to lift from a free hit.
4. (In previous rules versions hits in the area outside the circle in open play have been permitted but lifting one direction from a free hit prohibited).
5. Opponents must move from the ball when a free hit is awarded.
6. A free hit must be taken from within playing distance of the place of the offence for which it was awarded and the ball must be stationary when the free-hit is taken.As mentioned above, a 15 m hit is awarded if an attacking player commits a foul forward of that line, or if the ball passes over the back line off an attacker.
7. These free hits are taken in line with where the foul was committed (taking a line parallel with the sideline between where the offence was committed, or the ball went out of play).
8. When an attacking free hit is awarded within 5 m of the circle everyone including the person taking the penalty must be five metres from the circle and everyone apart from the person taking the free hit must be five metres away from the ball.
9. When taking an attacking free hit the ball may not be hit straight into the circle if you are within your attacking 23 metre area (25 yard area).
10. It must travel 5 metres before going in.

Category: Sport
Title: Field hockey
Section: Penalty corner

1. The short or penalty corner is awarded:
2. •     for an offence by a defender in the circle which does not prevent the probable scoring of a goal
3. •     for an intentional offence in the circle by a defender against an opponent who does not have possession of the ball or an opportunity to play the ball
4. •     for an intentional offence by a defender outside the circle but within the 23-metre area they are defending
5. •     for intentionally playing the ball over the back-line by a defender
6. •     when the ball becomes lodged in a player's clothing or equipment while in the circle they are defending

7. Short corners begin with five defenders (usually including the keeper) positioned behind the back line and at least 5 m from the 'insert' position of the ball.
8. All other players in the defending team must be beyond the centre line, that is not in their 'own' half of the pitch, until the ball is in play.
9. Attacking players begin the play standing outside the scoring circle, except for one attacker who starts the corner by playing the ball from a mark 10 m either side of the goal (the circle has a 14.63 m radius).
10. This player puts the ball into play by pushing or hitting the ball to the other attackers outside the circle; the ball must pass outside the circle and then put back into the circle before the attackers may make a shot at the goal from which a goal can be scored.
11. FIH rules do not forbid a shot at goal before the ball leaves the circle after being 'inserted', nor is a shot at the goal from outside the circle prohibited, but a goal cannot be scored at all if the ball has not gone out of the circle and cannot be scored from a shot from outside the circle if it is not again played by an attacking player before it enters the goal.For safety reasons, the first shot of a penalty corner must not exceed 460 mm high (the height of the "backboard" of the goal) at the point it crosses the goal line if it is hit.
12. However, if the ball is deemed to be below backboard height, the ball can be subsequently deflected above this height by another player (defender or attacker), providing that this deflection does not lead to danger.
13. Note that the "Slap" stroke (a sweeping motion towards the ball, where the stick is kept on or close to the ground when striking the ball) is classed as a hit, and so the first shot at goal must be below backboard height for this type of shot also.If the first shot at goal in a short corner situation is a push, flick or scoop, in particular the "drag flick" (which has become popular at international and national league standards), the shot is permitted to rise above the height of the backboard, as long as the shot is not deemed dangerous to any opponent.
14. This form of shooting was developed because it is not height restricted in the same way as the first hit shot at the goal and players with good technique are able to drag-flick with as much power as many others can hit a ball.

Category: Sport
Title: Handball
Section: Abstract

1. Handball (also known as team handball, Olympic handball, European team handball, European handball, or Borden ball) is a team sport in which two teams of seven players each (six outfield players and a goalkeeper on each team) pass a ball to throw it into the goal of the other team.
2. A standard match consists of two periods of 30 minutes, and the team that scores more goals wins.Modern handball is played on a court 40 by 20 meters (131 by 66 ft), with a goal in the center of each end.
3. The goals are surrounded by a 6-meter zone where only the defending goalkeeper is allowed; the goals must be scored by throwing the ball from outside the zone or while "diving" into it.
4. The sport is usually played indoors, but outdoor variants exist in the forms of field handball and Czech handball (which were more common in the past) and beach handball (also called sandball).
5. The game is quite fast and includes body contact, as the defenders try to stop the attackers from approaching the goal.
6. Goals are scored quite frequently; usually both teams score at least 20 goals each, and it is not uncommon for both teams to score more than 30 goals.The game was codified at the end of the 19th century in northern Europe, chiefly in Scandinavia and Germany.
7. The modern set of rules was published in 1917 in Germany, and had several revisions since.
8. The first international games were played under these rules for men in 1925 and for women in 1930.
9. Men's field handball was first played at the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin, and the next time at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, and has been an Olympics sport since.
10. Women's team handball was added at the 1976 Summer Olympics.The International Handball Federation was formed in 1946, and has 174 member federations.
11. The sport is most popular in continental Europe, whose countries have won every single medal in men's world championships since 1938, and all women's titles until 2013, when Brazil broke the series.
12. The game also enjoys popularity in Far East, north Africa and Brazil.

Category: Sport
Title: Handball
Section: International body

1. The International Handball Federation (IHF) is the administrative and controlling body for international handball.
2. The federation organizes world championships, held in uneven years, with separate competitions for men and women.The IHF World Men's Handball Championship 2009 and 2011 title holders were France; the 2013 title holders are Spain.The IHF World Women's Handball Championship 2009 title holders were Russia; the IHF 2011 Women’s World Championship title holders are Norway.
3. The IHF 2013 Women’s World Championship will be hosted in Serbia, December 6–22.The IHF is composed of five continental federations which organize continental championships held every other second year.
4. In addition to these competitions between national teams, the federations arrange international tournaments between club teams.
5. The federations and their corresponding tournaments and members are summarize in the following table:Handball is an Olympic sport played during the Summer Olympics.
6. It is also played during the Pan American Games, All-Africa Games, and Asian Games.
7. It is also played on Mediterranean games.

Category: Sport
Title: Modern pentathlon
Section: Abstract

1. The modern pentathlon is an Olympic sport that comprises five events: fencing, 200 m freestyle swimming, show jumping, and a final combined event of pistol shooting, and a 3200 m cross-country run.
2. The sport has been a core sport of the Olympic Games since 1912, and since 1949 an annual World Championship has been held.Originally the competition took place over four or five days; however in 1996 a one-day format was adopted in an effort to be more audience-friendly.
3. However, modern pentathlon, despite its long Olympic history, has had to justify its inclusion in the modern Olympic Games on frequent occasions.
4. On February 11, 2013 in Lausanne, the IOC confirmed modern pentathlon once again as one of the 25 core sports of the Olympic program through until 2020.
5. The governing body, UIPM, administers the international sport in more than 90 countries in all the continents of the world.

Category: Sport
Title: Gymnastics
Section: Rhythmic gymnastics

1. Only women compete in rhythmic gymnastics although there is a new version of this discipline for men being pioneered in Japan (see Men's rhythmic gymnastics).
2. This is a sport that combines elements of ballet, gymnastics, dance, and apparatus manipulation.
3. The sport involves the performance of five separate routines with the use of five apparatus; ball, ribbon, hoop, clubs, rope—on a floor area, with a much greater emphasis on the aesthetic rather than the acrobatic.
4. There are also group routines consisting of 5 gymnasts and 5 apparatuses of their choice.
5. Rhythmic routines are scored out of a possible 30 points; the score for artistry (choreography and music) is averaged with the score for difficulty of the moves and then added to the score for execution.International competitions are split between Juniors, under sixteen by their year of birth; and Seniors, for women sixteen and over again by their year of birth.
6. Gymnasts in Russia and Europe typically start training at a very young age and those at their peak are typically in their late teens (15–19) or early twenties.
7. The largest events in the sport are the Olympic Games, World Championships, European Championships, World Cup and Grand-Prix Series.

Category: Sport
Title: Gymnastics
Section: TeamGym

1. The TeamGym competition is one of the latest new events within the UEG.
2. The first official competition was held in Finland in 1996 and it takes place every even-numbered year.
3. TeamGym is a team competition for clubs and consist of three sections: women, men and mixed teams.TeamGym competitions exhibit gymnastic skills in three different disciplines; floor, tumbling and trampette.
4. In common for the performance is effective teamwork, good technique in the element and spectacular acrobatic elements.
5. The event is attractive for spectators and media as well as sponsors.
6. •     Floor Programme: All members of the Team take part in the floor program, composed of a mixture of dance, flexibility and skill.
7. The routine has to be skillfully choreographed and the judges look out for changes in shape.
8. There needs to be at least two spins, two jumps/leaps, two acrobatic elements, two balance/power elements, two section elements and one combination of elements.
9. These section elements are bodywaves for women's teams, power elements for men's teams and lifts for mixed teams.
10. Floor routines are performed to music.
11. •     Trampette: There are two components of this section of floor pregame.
12. Vault and trampette on its own.
13. One of the three total runs that the gymnasts make must be a vault run.
14. Generally the first round is chosen for each individual gymnast to perform the same move.
15. These are also performed to music.
16. •     Tumbling: Again, here there are three runs (rounds) involved.
17. One of which has to include all six gymnasts doing a forwards series.
18. Another run also has to include the gymnasts completing the same move.
19. Each series must have at least three different acrobatic elements.

Category: Sport
Title: Sailing
Section: Heeling

1. When a ship or boat leans over to one side, from the action of waves or from the centrifugal force of a turn or under wind pressure or from amount of exposed topsides, it is said to 'heel'.
2. A sailing boat that is over-canvassed and therefore heeling, may sail less efficiently depending on fundamental or opportunistic factors such as temporary nature of the feature (e.g.
3. wind gust), use (e.g.
4. racing), crew ability, point of sail, hull size & design.When a vessel is subject to a heeling force (such as wind pressure), vessel buoyancy & beam of the hull will counter-act the heeling force.
5. A weighted keel provides additional means to right the boat.
6. In some high-performance racing yachts, water ballast or the angle of a canting keel can be changed to provide additional righting force to counteract heeling.
7. The crew may move their personal weight to the high (upwind) side of the boat, this is called "hiking", which also changes the centre of gravity & produces a righting lever to reduce the degree of heeling.
8. Incidental benefits include faster vessel speed caused by more efficient action of the hull & sails.
9. Other options to reduce heeling include reducing exposed sail area & efficiency of the sail setting & a variant of hiking called "trapezing".
10. This can only be done if the vessel is designed for this, as in dinghy sailing.
11. A sailor can (usually involuntarily) try turning upwind in gusts (it is known as "rounding up").
12. This can lead to difficulties in controlling the vessel if over-canvassed.
13. Wind can be spilled from the sails by 'sheeting out', or loosening them.
14. The number of sails, their size and shape can be altered.
15. Raising the dinghy centreboard can reduce heeling by allowing more leeway.
16. The increasingly asymmetric underwater shape of the hull matching the increasing angle of heel may generate an increasing directional turning force into the wind.
17. The sails' centre of effort will also increase this turning effect or force on the vessel's motion due to increasing lever effect with increased heeling which shows itself as increased human effort required to steer a straight course.
18. Increased heeling reduces exposed sail area relative to the wind direction, so leading to an equilibrium state.
19. As more heeling force causes more heel, weather helm may be experienced.
20. This condition has a braking effect on the vessel but has the safety effect in that an excessively hard pressed boat will try and turn into the wind therefore reducing the forces on the sail.
21. Small amounts (≤5 degrees) of weather helm are generally considered desirable because of the consequent aerofoil lift effect from the rudder.
22. This aerofoil lift produces helpful motion to windward & the corollary of the reason why lee helm is dangerous.
23. Lee helm, the opposite of weather helm, is generally considered to be dangerous because the vessel turns away from the wind when the helm is released, thus increasing forces on the sail at a time when the helmsperson is not in control.

Category: Sport
Title: Sailing
Section: Other terms

1. Walls are called "bulkheads" or "ceilings", while the surfaces referred to as ceilings on land are called 'overheads'or 'deckheads'.
2. Floors are called 'soles' or "decks".
3. "Broken up" was the fate of a ship that hit a "rocky point" or was simply no longer wanted.
4. The toilet is traditionally called the 'head', the kitchen is the "galley".
5. When lines are tied off, this may be referred to as 'made fast' or 'belayed.'
6. Sails in different sail plans have unchanging names, however.
7. For the naming of sails, see sail-plan.

Category: Sport
Title: Track and field
Section: Middle distance

1. The most common middle-distance track events are the 800 metres, 1500 metres and mile run, although the 3000 metres may also be classified as a middle-distance event.
2. The 880 yard run, or half mile, was the forebear of the 800 m distance and it has its roots in competitions in the United Kingdom in the 1830s.
3. The 1500 m came about as a result of running three laps of a 500 m track, which was commonplace in continental Europe in the 20th century.Runners start the race from a standing position along a curved starting line and after hearing the starter's pistol they head towards the innermost track to follow the quickest route to the finish.
4. In 800 m races athletes begin at a staggered starting point before the turn in the track and they must remain in their lanes for the first 100 m of the race.
5. This rule was introduced to reduce the amount of physical jostling between runners in the early stages of the race.
6. Physiologically, these middle-distance events demand that athletes have good aerobic and anaerobic energy producing systems, and also that they have strong speed endurance.The 1500 m and mile run events have historically been some of the most prestigious track and field events.
7. Swedish rivals Gunder Hägg and Arne Andersson broke each other's 1500 m and mile world records on a number of occasions in the 1940s.
8. The prominence of the distances were maintained by Roger Bannister, who (in 1954) was the first to run the long-elusive four-minute mile, and Jim Ryun's exploits served to popularise interval training.
9. Races between British rivals Sebastian Coe, Steve Ovett and Steve Cram characterised middle-distance running in 1980s.
10. From the 1990s onwards, North Africans such as Noureddine Morceli of Algeria and Hicham El Guerrouj of Morocco came to dominate the 1500 and mile events.Beyond the short distances of sprinting events, factors such as an athlete's reactions and top speed becomes less important, while qualities such as pace, race tactics and endurance become more so.

Category: Sport
Title: Track and field
Section: Javelin throw

1. As an implement of war and hunting, javelin throwing began in prehistoric times.
2. Along with the discus, the javelin was the second throwing event in the ancient Olympic pentathlon.
3. Records from 708 BC show two javelin competition types co-existing: throwing at a target and throwing the javelin for distance.
4. It was the latter type from which the modern event derives.
5. In ancient competitions, athletes would wrap an "ankyle" (thin leather strip) around the javelin that acted as a sling to facilitate extra distance.
6. The javelin throw gained much popularity in Scandinavia in the late 18th century and athletes from the region are still among the most dominant throwers in men's competitions.
7. The modern event features a short run up on a track and then the thrower releases the javelin before the foul line.The first Olympic men's javelin throw contest was held in 1908 and a women's competition was introduced in 1932.
8. The first javelins were made of various types of wood, but in the 1950s, former athlete Bud Held introduced a hollow javelin, then a metal javelin, both of which increased throwers performances.
9. Another former athlete, Miklós Németh invented the rough-tailed javelin and throws reached in excess of 100 m – edging towards the limits of stadia.
10. The distances and the increasing number of horizontal landings led the IAAF to redesign the men's javelin to reduce distance and increase the implement's downward pitching moment to allow for easier measurement.
11. Rough-tailed designs were banned in 1991 and all marks achieved with such javelins were removed from the record books.
12. The women's javelin underwent a similar redesign in 1999.
13. The current javelin specifications are 2.6 to 2.7 m in length and 800 grams in weight for men, and between 2.2 to 2.3 m and 600 g for women.

Category: Sport
Title: Olympic weightlifting
Section: History

1. Competition among people concerning who can lift the heaviest weight has been recorded in diverse and ancient civilizations as early as the earliest known recordings of such human events, including those found in Egypt, China and in ancient Greece.
2. Today, the modern sport of weightlifting traces its origins to the European competitions of the 19th century.
3. The first male world champion was crowned in 1891.
4. Women's competition did not exist, and the weightlifters were not categorised by height or weight.The first Olympic Games of 1896 included weightlifting in the Field event of the predecessor to today's Track and Field or Athletics event.
5. During the 1900 Olympic Games, there was no weightlifting event.
6. Weightlifting resumed as an event, again in Athletics, in 1904 but was omitted from the Games of 1908 and 1912.
7. These were the last Games until after the First World War.
8. In these early Games, a distinction was drawn between lifting with 'one hand' only and lifting with 'two hands'.
9. The winner of the 'one hand' competition in 1896 was Launceston Elliot, while the winner of the 'two hands' event was Viggo Jensen of Denmark.
10. In 1920, weightlifting returned to the Olympics and, for the first time, as an event in its own right.
11. At these Games, which took place in Antwerp, Belgium, fourteen nations competed.
12. The competition lifts were the 'one hand' snatch, the 'one hand' clean and jerk and the 'two hands' clean and jerk.
13. At the next Olympic Games, in Paris, France, in 1924, the 'two hands' press and the 'two hands' snatch were added to the programme, making a total of five lifts.
14. In the Olympic Games after 1920, instead of requiring all competitors to compete against each other regardless of size, weight classes were introduced and, by the 1932 Olympic Games, weightlifting was divided into five weight divisions.
15. In 1928, the sport dropped the 'one hand' exercises altogether leaving only the three remaining exercises: the clean and press, the snatch and the clean and jerk.
16. By 1972, the clean and press was discontinued because athletes started to push with legs and bend backwards instead of strictly pressing the weight overhead, and this left the sole elements of what is today's modern Olympic weightlifting programme – the snatch and the clean and jerk.
17. The snatch entails pulling with a very wide grip the barbell overhead without pressing out with the arms.
18. It is a very precise lift that can be nullified by a lack of balance of the athlete.
19. The clean and jerk is more forgiving using a narrower grip pull the bar to the shoulders and then using the strength of the legs push until arms reach full extension without a press out.
20. A competition for women was introduced at the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney, Australia.As early as 1987, there were official world championships awarded to women weightlifters such as Karyn Marshall and Judy Glenney.
21. In 2011 the International Weightlifting Federation ruled that athletes could wear a full-body "unitard" under the customary weightlifting uniform.
22. Kulsoom Abdullah became the first woman to do so at the U.S. National Championships that year, and athletes are allowed to do so at the Olympics.
23. IWF rules previously stated that an athlete's knees and elbows must be visible so officials can determine if a lift is correctly executed.

Category: Sport
Title: Olympic weightlifting
Section: Equipment

1. Olympic weightlifting uses a steel bar with rotating sleeves (also known as a barbell) which hold rubber-coated discs of different weights.
2. The weight plates, typically referred to as "bumper plates" because of their rubber design, weigh between 0.5kg and 25kg.
3. These plates are secured to the bar using collars on each sleeve that weigh exactly 2.5kg each.
4. Lifters typically wear a one-piece, close-fitting leotard often called a singlet.
5. The wearing of a t-shirt underneath the singlet is optional.
6. A weightlifting belt of 120mm maximum width may also be worn to provide lower back support.
7. Perhaps the piece of equipment most peculiar to Olympic weightlifting are the shoes worn by lifters.
8. Weightlifting shoes are typically designed with a raised heel of 0.5" to 1.5" and one or two metatarsal straps that tighten across the instep of the shoe.
9. The shoes are designed for maximum stability while remaining flexible in the toebox.
10. This allows the lifter to come up on their toes and catch the weight on the ball of their back foot during the "jerk" movement of their lift.
11. The raised heel helps the lifter maintain an upright torso while catching the bar and also allows for a deeper squat under the bar.

Category: Sport
Title: Water polo
Section: Defense

1. Defensive positions are often the same positionally, but just switched from offense to defense.
2. For example, the centre forward or hole set, who directs the attack on offense, on defense is known as "hole D" (also known as set guard, hole guard, hole check, pit defense or two-meter defense), and guards the opposing team's center forward (also called the hole).
3. Defense can be played man-to-man or in zones, such as a 2–4 (four defenders along the goal line).
4. It can also be played as a combination of the two in what is known as an "M drop" defense, in which the point defender moves away ("sloughs off") his man into a zone in order to better defend the center position.
5. In this defense, the two wing defenders split the area furthest from the goal, allowing them a clearer lane for the counter-attack if their team recovers the ball.

Category: Sport
Title: Water polo
Section: Water polo equipment

1. equipment.Little player equipment is needed to play water polo.
2. Items required in water polo include:
3. •    Ball: A water polo ball is constructed of waterproof material to allow it to float on the water.
4. The cover is textured to give players additional grip.
5. The size of the ball is different for men's, women's and junior games.
6. •    Caps: A water polo cap is used to protect the players' heads and ears, and to make them identifiable from afar.
7. Home team field players wear numbered white caps; Visiting team field players wear numbered dark-colored or black caps.
8. Both starting goalkeepers wear red caps (sometimes quartered), numbered "1" (substitute goalies' caps are numbered either "13" for FINA international play or "15" for NCAA play) Caps are fitted with ear protectors.
9. •    Goals: Two goals are needed in order to play water polo.
10. These can either be put on the side of the pool, or in the pool using floaters.
11. •    Mouthguard: A mouthguard is not mandatory in most tournaments, but is recommended.
12. •    Swimwear: Male water polo players wear either swim briefs or jammers (thigh-length trunks).
13. Female players must wear a one-piece swimsuit.
14. Suit-grabbing fouls are common, so players often wear tight-fitting suits, and may layer on several suits at a time for additional security.
15. Many swimwear labels also sell specialized water polo suits that feature reinforced stitching and tougher fabric.
16. Female water polo suits are generally one-piece outfits which do not have open backs, but zip securely up the back so as to not have straps that can be easily grabbed.

Category: Sport
Title: Rugby union
Section: Women's rugby union

1. Records of women's rugby football date back to the late 19th century, with the first documented source being Emily Valentine's writings, stating that she set up a rugby team in Portora Royal School in Enniskillen, Ireland in 1887.
2. Although there are reports of early women's matches in New Zealand and France, one of the first notable games to prove primary evidence was the 1917 war-time encounter between Cardiff Ladies and Newport Ladies; a photo of which shows the Cardiff team before the match at the Cardiff Arms Park.
3. In the past 30 years the game has grown in popularity among female athletes, and, according to the IRB, is now played in over 100 countries.The English based Women's Rugby Football Union (WRFU), responsible for women's rugby in England, Scotland Ireland and Wales, was founded in 1983, and is the oldest formally organised national governing body for women's rugby.
4. This was replaced in 1994 by the Rugby Football Union for Women (RFUW) in England with each of the other Home Nations governing their own countries.
5. The premier international competition in rugby union for women is the Women's Rugby World Cup, first held in 1991.
6. Since 1994 it has been held every four years.

Category: Sport
Title: Rugby union
Section: Statistics and records

1. According to a 2011 report by the Centre for the International Business of Sport at Coventry University, there are now over four and a half million people playing rugby union or one of its variants organised by the IRB.
2. This is an increase of 19 percent since the previous report in 2007.
3. The report also claimed that since 2007 participation has grown by 33 percent in Africa, 22 percent in South America and 18 percent in Asia and North America.
4. In 2014 the IRB published a breakdown of the total number of players worldwide by national unions.
5. It recorded a total of 6.6 million players globally, of those, 2.36 million were registered members playing for a club affiliated to their country's union.Rugby union's premier event, the Rugby World Cup, has continued to grow since its inception in 1987.
6. The first tournament, in which 16 teams competed for the title, was broadcast to 17 countries with an accumulated total of 230 million television viewers.
7. Ticket sales during the pool stages and finals of the same tournament was less than a million.
8. The 2007 World Cup was contested by 94 countries with ticket sales of 3,850,000 over the pool and final stage.
9. The accumulated television audience for the event, then broadcast to 200 countries, was 4.2 billion.The most capped international player from the tier 1 nations is Irish and British Lions centre Brian O'Driscoll who has played in 141 internationals.
10. While the top scoring tier 1 international player is New Zealand's Dan Carter, who has amassed 1442 points during his career.
11. In April 2010 Lithuania broke the record of consecutive international wins previously held by New Zealand and South Africa, which was 17 consecutive wins against tier 1 nations, with their 18th win in tier 2 in a match against Serbia.
12. The highest scoring international match between two recognised unions was Hong Kong's 164–13 victory over Singapore on 27 October 1994 While the largest winning margin of 152 points is held by two countries, Japan (a 155–3 win over Chinese Taipei) and Argentina (152–0 over Paraguay) both in 2002.

Category: Sport
Title: Karate
Section: Abstract

1. Karate developed in the Ryukyu Kingdom.
2. It was brought to the Japanese mainland in the early 20th century during a time of cultural exchanges between the Japanese and the Ryukyuans.
3. It was systematically taught in Japan after the Taisho era.
4. In 1922 the Japanese Ministry of Education invited Gichin Funakoshi to Tokyo to give a karate demonstration.
5. In 1924 Keio University established the first university karate club in Japan and by 1932, major Japanese universities had karate clubs.
6. In this era of escalating Japanese militarism, the name was changed from ("Chinese hand" or "Tang hand") to ("empty hand") – both of which are pronounced "karate" – to indicate that the Japanese wished to develop the combat form in Japanese style.
7. After World War II, Okinawa became an important United States military site and karate became popular among servicemen stationed there.The martial arts movies of the 1960s and 1970s served to greatly increase the popularity of martial arts around the world, and in English the word "karate" began to be used in a generic way to refer to all striking-based Oriental martial arts.
8. Karate schools began appearing across the world, catering to those with casual interest as well as those seeking a deeper study of the art.Shigeru Egami, Chief Instructor of Shotokan Dojo, opined "that the majority of followers of karate in overseas countries pursue karate only for its fighting techniques ... Movies and television ... depict karate as a mysterious way of fighting capable of causing death or injury with a single blow ... the mass media present a pseudo art far from the real thing."
9. Shoshin Nagamine said "Karate may be considered as the conflict within oneself or as a life-long marathon which can be won only through self-discipline, hard training and one's own creative efforts.
10. "In 2009, in the 121st International Olympic Committee voting, karate did not receive the necessary two-thirds majority vote to become an Olympic sport.
11. Karate was being considered for the 2020 Olympics,—however at a meeting of the IOC's executive board, held in Russia on May 29, 2013, it was decided that karate (along with wushu and several other non-martial arts) would not be considered for inclusion in 2020 at the IOC's 125th session in Buenos Aires, Argentina, in September 2013.Web Japan (sponsored by the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs) claims there are 50 million karate practitioners worldwide, while the World Karate Federation claims there are 100 million practitioners around the world.

Category: Sport
Title: Karate
Section: Canada

1. and its influence outside Japan.Canada.Karate began in Canada in the 1930s and 1940s as Japanese people immigrated to the country.
2. Karate was practised quietly without a large amount of organization.
3. During the Second World War, many Japanese-Canadian families were moved to the interior of British Columbia.
4. Masaru Shintani, at the age of 13, began to study Shorin-Ryu karate in the Japanese camp under Kitigawa.
5. In 1956 after 9 years of training with Kitigawa, Shintani travelled to Japan and met Hironori Otsuka (Wado Ryu).
6. In 1958 Otsuka invited Shintani to join his organization Wado Kai, and in 1969 he asked Shintani to officially call his style Wado.In Canada during this same time, karate was also introduced by Masami Tsuruoka who had studied in Japan in the 1940s under Tsuyoshi Chitose.
7. In 1954 Tsuruoka initiated the first karate competition in Canada and laid the foundation for the National Karate Association.In the late 1950s Shintani moved to Ontario and began teaching karate and judo at the Japanese Cultural Centre in Hamilton.
8. In 1966 he began (with Otsuka's endorsement) the Shintani Wado Kai Karate Federation.
9. During the 1970s Otsuka appointed Shintani the Supreme Instructor of Wado Kai in North America.
10. In 1979, Otsuka publicly promoted Shintani to hachidan (8th dan) and privately gave him a kudan certificate (9th dan), which was revealed by Shintani in 1995.
11. Shintani and Otsuka visited each other in Japan and Canada several times, the last time in 1980 two years prior to Otsuka's death.
12. Shintani died May 7, 2000.

Category: Sport
Title: Squash (sport)
Section: Playing equipment

1. Standard racquets are governed by the rules of the game.
2. Traditionally they were made of laminated wood (typically ash), with a small strung area using natural gut strings.
3. After a rule change in the mid-1980s, they are now almost always made of composite materials or metals (graphite, Kevlar, titanium, boron) with synthetic strings.
4. Modern racquets have maximum dimensions of 686 mm (27.0 in) long and 215 mm (8.5 in) wide, with a maximum strung area of 500 square centimetres (90 sq in), the permitted maximum weight is , but most have a weight between 90 and 150 grams (3–5.3 oz.
5. ).Squash balls are between 39.5 and 40.5 mm in diameter, and have a weight of 23 to 25 grams.
6. They are made with two pieces of rubber compound, glued together to form a hollow sphere and buffed to a matte finish.
7. Different balls are provided for varying temperature and atmospheric conditions and standards of play: more experienced players use slow balls that have less bounce than those used by less experienced players (slower balls tend to "die" in court corners, rather than "standing up" to allow easier shots).
8. Depending on its specific rubber composition, a squash ball has the property that it bounces more at higher temperatures.
9. Squash balls must be hit dozens of times to warm them up at the beginning of a session; cold squash balls have very little bounce.Small colored dots on the ball indicate its dynamic level (bounciness), and thus the standard of play for which it is suited.
10. The recognized speed colors indicating the degree of dynamism are:
11. •    :::::

12. Some ball manufacturers such as Dunlop use a different method of grading balls based on experience.
13. They still have the equivalent dot rating, but are named to help choose a ball that is appropriate for one's skill level.
14. The four different ball types are Intro (Blue dot), Progress (Red dot), Competition (single yellow dot) and Pro (double yellow dot).The "double-yellow dot" ball, introduced in 2000, is the competition standard, replacing the earlier "yellow-dot" ball.
15. There is also an "orange dot" ball.Players wear comfortable sports clothing.
16. In competition, men usually wear shorts and a t-shirt, tank top or a polo shirt.
17. Women normally wear a skirt or skort and a t-shirt or a tank top, or a sports dress.
18. The National Institutes of Health recommends wearing goggles with polycarbonate lenses.Many squash venues mandate the use of eye protection and some association rules require that all juniors and doubles players must wear eye protection.

Category: Sport
Title: Squash (sport)
Section: Types of shots played

1. There are many types of shots played that lead to interesting games and strategy.
2. •     Straight drive: The ball is hit parallel and close to a side wall to travel deep to the back of the court (the 'basic' squash shot).
3. Often referred to as a 'good length' shot.
4. •     Boast: The ball is played off a side wall at an angle, or the back wall, before hitting the front wall.
5. •     Volley: The ball is hit 'on the full' (before it touches the floor), usually directly to the front wall
6. •     Drop shot: The ball is hit gently against the front wall, to fall softly to the floor in the front corner.
7. •     Lob: The ball is hit softly and high on the front wall and with a high arc, so that it falls in a back corner of the court.
8. •     Cross Court: The ball is hit to the front wall from the right side to the left (or vice versa).
9. •     Kill: The ball is hit hard and low on the front wall so that it travels no farther than half court.
10. •     Trickle boast: A 'short' boast where the ball is hit to the side wall at the front of the court (often disguised as a drive or drop shot).
11. •     Squeeze boast: A more difficult shot which is hit from the front of the court when the ball is very close to the side wall.
12. Has the same effect as the trickle boast but is more deceptive because of its difficulty.
13. •     Nick shot: the ball is 'volleyed' or hit off a bounce to strike the front wall then the junction of the side wall and floor (the 'nick') giving the ball little or no bounce.
14. •     Rolling nick shot: When the nick shot is hit extremely well, the ball will roll along the floor (this is a more advanced shot that is a variation of the kill shot).
15. •     Back wall boast: the ball is hit moderately hard and high off the back wall, so that it goes the length of the room and hits (usually low) off the front wall.
16. •     Philadelphia (or corkscrew): A shot played diagonally upwards into the front corner hitting the front wall first and then the side wall.
17. The ball then lobs over the court with significant spin.
18. Ideally it hits the opposite side wall at the back and travels parallel to the rear wall making a return very difficult.
19. This shot is a favourite in exhibition squash but is susceptible to being volleyed.
20. •     Skid boast: A shot played from the back corners of the court where the ball is hit high along the sidewall with a small angle so that it hits the sidewall first, then hits high in the middle of the front wall continuing to cross the court while high in the air ideally hitting the opposite sidewall and landing close to the backwall to go past the opponent.
21. As with the Philadelphia it is suceptible to being volleyed.
22. •     Mizuki: This shot is hit as a volley.
23. Unlike a normal volley, the Mizuki shot is hit with the other side of the racquet by turning the wrist which deceives the direction of the ball.
24. •     Reverse angle: a boast where the opposite sidewall is hit first.

Category: Sport
Title: Wakeboarding
Section: Boards

1. Boards are buoyant with the core usually made up of foam, honeycomb or wood mixed with resin and coated with fiberglass.
2. Metal screws are inserted to attach bindings and fins.The configuration and positioning of the fins and bindings vary according to rider preference and are adjusted for a variety of reasons.
3. A wakeboarder will change the type of fins used for different types of tricks.
4. For example, shallow fins (which do not protrude into the water very far) are better for surface tricks, such as flat spins.
5. Many newer board models contain small moulded fins on the board, allowing the rider to use smaller centre fins and also to create less drag.Board hardware is often set up to allow a rider to ride "Switch" or "Fakie," with either foot forward.
6. Such setups are usually symmetrical in layout.
7. New riders normally set up their boards to be comfortable to ride with their "natural" foot forward, which does not allow for riding Switch without modifications.For best results and easy wakeboarding, this sport is normally done in lakes, though the intercoastal waterways are also becoming popular.

Category: Sport
Title: Wakeboarding
Section: Fins and placement

1. The closer the fins are placed towards the centre of the wakeboard, the quicker and better the wakeboard releases from the wake.
2. The farther out towards the tip and tail they are placed, the longer the wakeboard will stay hooked into the wake and it won’t release as well.Long based finsTheir effect is almost the same as a short fin with a long base because they have a similar amount of surface area.
3. Long-based fins release better, give the wakeboard a loose, snowboard-like feel when riding flat through the water, and they hold up better on rails and ramps.Moulded finsThese are just big channels in the board that act like fins and hold up on rails and ramps.
4. Moulded fins are slippery, but most boards have a removable centre fin.Multi-finned set-upsThese capture the maximum edge hold and aggressiveness into the wake and through the wake.Canted side finsThese are fins that lean out on an angle.
5. These fins are not as active when the wakeboard is riding flat through the water, but the more the rider leans on edge, the more the wakeboard hooks up.
6. The inside fin digs while the outside lifts, creating leverage to help the wakeboard edge hard.
7. Great for 50-50 grinds, nose presses and tail presses.Cupped side finsThey have the same effect as canted fins but add more of a push-pull effect.
8. The cupped fin allows for the use of a smaller fin but still gets the hold of a bigger fin due to the increased surface area of the cupped side of the fin.
9. These fins are very deceiving – they look small and loose but really aren’t.No FinsSome riders prefer to ride finless, as some boards are specifically designed for cable parks or other uses, some uses of which can benefit from a finless design.

Category: Sport
Title: Wushu (sport)
Section: Traditional weapons routines

1. There is also a traditional weapons category, which often includes the following:
2. •    Changsuijian (長穗劍) – Long-Tasseled Sword
3. •    Shuangshoujian (雙手劍) – Two-Handed Sword
4. •    Jiujiebian (九節鞭) – Nine Section Whip
5. •    Sanjiegun (三節棍) – Three Section Staff
6. •    Shengbiao (繩鏢) – Rope Dart
7. •    Dadao (大刀) – Great Sword
8. •    Pudao (撲刀) – Horse Knife
9. •    Emeici (峨嵋刺) – Emei Daggers
10. •    Shuangdao (雙刀) – Double Broadsword
11. •    Shuangjian (雙劍) – Double Straight-Sword
12. •    Shuangbian (雙鞭) – Double Nine Section Whips
13. •    Shuanggou (雙鈎) – Double Hook-sword

Category: Sport
Title: Wushu (sport)
Section: Wushu as an Olympic event

1. The IWUF placed a bid to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to have wushu included in future Olympic Games, but did not meet with success.
2. However, the IOC allowed China to organize an international wushu event during the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, but this event is not one of the 28 official Olympic sports, nor is it a demonstration event.
3. Instead, it was called the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games Wushu Tournament.
4. Wushu was one of 8 sports that was considered for inclusion in the 2020 Summer Olympics.
5. On May 29, 2013, Wushu's bid was rejected.

Category: Sport
Title: Netball
Section: Abstract

1. Netball is a ball sport played by two teams of seven players.
2. Its development, derived from early versions of basketball, began in England in the 1890s.
3. By 1960, international playing rules had been standardised for the game, and the International Federation of Netball and Women's Basketball (later renamed the International Netball Federation (INF)) was formed.
4. As of 2011, the INF comprises more than 60 national teams organized into five global regions.Games are played on a rectangular court with raised goal rings at each end.
5. Each team attempts to score goals by passing a ball down the court and shooting it through its goal ring.
6. Players are assigned specific positions, which define their roles within the team and restrict their movement to certain areas of the court.
7. During general play, a player with the ball can hold onto it for only three seconds before shooting for a goal or passing to another player.
8. The winning team is the one that scores the most goals.
9. Netball games are 60 minutes long.
10. Variations have been developed to increase the game's pace and appeal to a wider audience.Netball is most popular in Commonwealth nations, specifically in schools, and is predominantly played by women.
11. According to the INF, netball is played by more than 20 million people in more than 80 countries.
12. Major transnational competitions take place, including the Netball Superleague in Great Britain and the ANZ Championship in Australia and New Zealand.
13. Three major competitions take place internationally: the quadrennial World Netball Championships, the Commonwealth Games, and the yearly World Netball Series.
14. In 1995, netball became an International Olympic Committee recognised sport.

Category: Sport
Title: Netball
Section: Description and rules

1. The objective of a game is to score more goals than the opposition.
2. Goals are scored when a team member positioned in the attacking shooting circle shoots the ball through the goal ring.
3. The goal rings are in diameter and sit atop -high goal posts that have no backboards.
4. A -radius semi-circular "shooting circle" is an area at each end of the court.
5. The goal posts are located within the shooting circle.
6. Each team defends one shooting circle and attacks the other.
7. The netball court is long, wide, and divided lengthwise into thirds.
8. The ball is usually made of leather or rubber, measures in circumference, and weighs .
9. A normal game consists of four 15-minute quarters and can be played outdoors or in a covered stadium.Each team is allowed seven players on the court.
10. Each player is assigned a specific position, which limits their movement to a certain area of the court.
11. A "bib" worn by each player contains a two letter abbreviation of indicating this position.
12. Only two positions are permitted in the attacking shooting circle, and can therefore shoot for a goal.
13. Similarly, only two positions are permitted in the defensive shooting circle; they try to prevent the opposition from shooting goals.
14. Other players are restricted to two thirds of the court, with the exception of the Centre, who may move anywhere on the court except for a shooting circle.At the beginning of every quarter and after a goal has been scored, play starts with a player in the centre position passing the ball from the centre of the court.
15. These "centre passes" alternate between the teams, regardless of which team scored the last goal.
16. When the umpire blows the whistle to restart play, four players from each team can move into the centre third to receive the pass.
17. The centre pass must be caught or touched in the centre third.
18. The ball is then moved up and down the court through passing and must be touched by a player in each adjacent third of the court.
19. Players can hold the ball for only three seconds at any time.
20. It must be released before the foot they were standing on when they caught it touches the ground again.
21. Contact between players is only permitted if it does not impede an opponent or the general play.
22. When defending a pass or shot players must be at least away from the player with the ball.
23. If illegal contact is made, the player who contacted cannot participate in play until the player taking the penalty has passed or shot the ball.
24. If the ball is held in two hands and either dropped or a shot at goal is missed, the same player cannot be the first to touch it unless it first rebounds off the goal.

Category: Sport
Title: Croquet
Section: Association

1. Variations.Association.Association croquet is the name of an advanced game of croquet, played at international level.
2. It involves four balls teamed in pairs, with both balls going through every hoop for one pair to win.
3. The game's distinguishing feature is the "croquet" shot: when certain balls hit other balls, extra shots are allowed.
4. The six hoops are arranged three at each end of the court, with a centre peg.In association croquet one side takes the black and blue balls, the other takes red and yellow.At each turn, players can choose to play with either of their balls for that turn.At the start of a turn, the player plays a stroke.
5. If the player either hits the ball through the correct hoop ("runs" the hoop), or hits another ball (a "roquet"), the turn continues.Following a roquet, the player picks up his or her own ball and puts it down next to the ball that it hit.
6. The next shot is played with the two balls touching: this is the "croquet stroke" from which the game takes its name.After the croquet stroke, the player plays a "continuation" stroke, during which the player may again attempt to make a roquet or run a hoop.
7. Each of the other three balls may be roqueted once in a turn before a hoop is run, after which they become available to be roqueted again.The winner of the game is the team who completes the set circuit of six hoops (and then back again the other way), with both balls, and then strikes the centre peg (making a total of 13 points per ball = 26).Good players may make "breaks" of several hoops in a single turn.
8. The best players may take a ball round a full circuit in one turn.
9. "Advanced play" (a variant of association play for expert players) gives penalties to a player who runs certain hoops in a turn, to allow the opponent a chance of getting back into the game; feats of skill such as triple peels or better, in which the partner ball (or occasionally an opponent ball) is caused to run a number of hoops in a turn by the striker's ball help avoid these penalties.A handicap system ('bisques') provides less experienced players a chance of winning against more formidable opponents.
10. Players of all ages and both sexes compete on level terms.The World Championships are organised by the World Croquet Federation (WCF) and usually take place every 2 or 3 years.
11. The New Zealand team won the last MacRobertson International Croquet Shield tournament, which is the major international test tour trophy in association croquet.
12. It is contested every three to four years between Australia, Great Britain, the United States and New Zealand.
13. Historically the British have been the dominant force, winning 14 times out of the 20 times the event has been held.
14. In individual competition, the UK is often divided by subnational country (England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales).
15. Unlike most sports, men and women compete and are ranked together.
16. As of 2013, the Association Croquet World Champion is Robert Fletcher of Australia and the Women's Association Croquet World Champion is Jenny Clarke of New Zealand.The world's top 10 association croquet players as of February 2014 are Robert Fletcher (Australia), Chris Clarke (New Zealand), Reg Bamford (South Africa), Paddy Chapman (New Zealand), Aaron Westerby (New Zealand), Greg Bryant (New Zealand), Toby Garrison (New Zealand), Robert Fulford (England), David Maugham (England), and Jamie Burch (England).Three women have won the British Open Championship: Lily Gower in 1905, Dorothy Steel in 1925, 1933, 1935 and 1936, and Hope Rotherham in 1960.
17. While male players are in the majority at club level in the UK, the opposite is the case in Australia and New Zealand.The governing body in England is The Croquet Association, which has been the driving force of the development of the game.
18. The rules and tournament regulations are now maintained by the International Laws Committee, established by the croquet associations of England and Wales (CA), Australia (ACA), New Zealand (CNZ) and the United States (USCA).

Category: Sport
Title: Croquet
Section: Garden

1. Garden croquet is widely played in the UK.
2. The rules are easy to learn and the game can be played on lawns of almost any size but usually around by .
3. The rules are similar to those described above for Association Croquet with three major differences:
4. •     The starting point for all balls is a spot three feet in from the boundary directly in front of hoop1.
5. •     If a strikers ball goes off, there is no penalty, it comes back on three feet and the turn continues.
6. •     In a croquet stroke the croqueted ball does not have to move when the strikers ball is struck.

7. This version of the game is easy for beginners to learn.
8. The main Garden Croquet Club in the UK is the Bygrave Croquet Club which is a private club with five lawns.
9. Other clubs also use garden croquet as an introduction to the game, notably the Hampstead Heath Croquet Club and the Watford Croquet Club.

Category: Sport
Title: Tug of war
Section: Origins

1. The origins of tug of war are uncertain, but it is beyond dispute that this once royal sport was practised in ancient Egypt, Greece and China, where it was held in legend that the Sun and Moon played Tug of War over the light and darkness.
2. It is also widely believed the sport was made popular in Great Britain by Lord Elliott Simpson, in the 16th Century.
3. Simpson was a keen tugger.According to a Tang dynasty book, The Notes of Feng, tug of war, under the name "hook pulling"(牵钩), was used by the military commander of the State of Chu during the Spring and Autumn Period (8th century BC to 5th century BC) to train warriors.
4. During the Tang dynasty, Emperor Xuanzong of Tang promoted large-scale tug of war games, using ropes of up to 167 meters or (547.9 feet) with shorter ropes attached and more than 500 people on each end of the rope.
5. Each side also had its own team of drummers to encourage the participants.In ancient Greece the sport was called "helkustinda" (Greek: ἑλκυστίνδα), "efelkustinda" (ἐφελκυστίνδα) and "dielkustinda" (διελκυστίνδα), which derives from "dielkō" (διέλκω), meaning amongst others "I pull through", all deriving from the verb "helkō" (ἕλκω), "I draw, I pull".
6. "Helkustinda" and "efelkustinda" seem to have been ordinary versions of tug of war, while "dielkustinda" had no rope, according to Julius Pollux.
7. It is possible that the teams held hands when pulling, which would have increased difficulty, since handgrips are more difficult to sustain than a grip of a rope.
8. Tug of war games in ancient Greece were among the most popular games used for strength and would help build strength needed for battle in full armor.
9. Archeological evidence shows that tug of war was also popular in India in 12th century AD:Tug of war stories about heroic champions from Scandinavia and Germany circulate Western Europe where Viking warriors pull animal skins over open pits of fire in tests of strength and endurance in preparation for battle and plunder.1500 and 1600 – tug of war is popularised during tournaments in French châteaux gardens and later in Great Britain1800 – tug of war begins a new tradition among seafaring men who were required to tug on lines to adjust sails while ships were under way and even in battle.The Mohave Indians occasionally used tug-of-war matches as means of settling disputes.The "Oxford English Dictionary" says that the phrase "tug of war" originally meant "the decisive contest; the real struggle or tussle; a severe contest for supremacy".
10. Only in the 19th century was it used as a term for an athletic contest between two teams who haul at the opposite ends of a rope.

Category: Sport
Title: Tug of war
Section: Risk of Injury

1. In addition to injuries from falling and back strains, (some of which may be serious), catastrophic injuries may result in the form of finger, hand or even arm amputations.
2. Amputations or avulsions may result from two causes: looping or wrapping the rope around a hand or wrist, and from the elastic recoil of the broken rope if the rope breaks.
3. Amateur organizers of tugs of war may underestimate the forces generated, or overestimate the breaking strength of common ropes, and may thus be unaware of the possible consequences if a rope parts in peoples' hands under tons of tension.
4. The broken ends of an elastic polymer such as common nylon reach high speeds and can easily sever fingers.
5. For this reason, specially engineered tug of war ropes exist that can withstand the forces generated.
6. Some notable tug of war accidents include:
7. •    Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, June 13, 1978, rope parted, five teenagers lost fingers or fingertips, 200 other injuries.
8. •    Chattanooga, Tennessee, June 9, 1995, a man had his hand torn off (avulsion) by sudden pull (his hand was in a loop).
9. •    Taipei, Taiwan, October 25, 1997, rope parted, two men suffered arm amputations (details below).
10. •    Australia, September, 2002, 11-year-old boy had several fingers cut to the bone and nearly severed.
11. •    Denver, Colorado, October 12, 2007, two teenage boys, rope looped around hands, suffered hand amputations.
12. •    Digby, Nova Scotia, October 25, 2010, rope looped around hand, man lost four fingers.
13. •    El Monte, California, February 4, 2013, rope parted, teenage boy and girl each suffered multi-finger amputations.
14. •    Budapest, Hungary, September 17, 2013, rope parted, seven student injured, three of them severely.

Category: Sport
Title: Scuba diving
Section: Diver propulsion

1. Personal mobility is enhanced by fins and optionally diver propulsion vehicles.
2. Fins have a large blade area and use the more powerful leg muscles, so are much more efficient for propulsion and manoeuvring thrust than arm and hand movements, but require skill to provide fine control.Streamlining dive gear will reduce drag and improve mobility.
3. Balanced trim which allows the diver to align in any desired direction also improves streamlining by presenting the smallest section area to the direction of movement and allows propulsion thrust to be used more efficiently.Occasionally a diver may be towed using a "sled", an unpowered device towed behind a surface vessel which conserves the diver's energy and allows more distance to be covered for a given air consumption and bottom time.
4. The depth is usually controlled by the diver by using diving planes or by tilting the whole sled.
5. Some sleds are faired to reduce drag on the diver.

Category: Sport
Title: Scuba diving
Section: Nitrogen narcosis

1. Nitrogen narcosis or inert gas narcosis is a reversible alteration in consciousness producing a state similar to alcohol intoxication in divers who breathe high pressure gas at depth.
2. The mechanism is similar to that of nitrous oxide, or "laughing gas," administered as anesthesia.
3. Being "narced" can impair judgment and make diving very dangerous.
4. Narcosis starts to affect some divers at 66 feet (20 m).
5. At this depth, narcosis manifests itself as a slight giddiness.
6. The effects increase drastically with the increase in depth.
7. Almost all divers are able to notice the effects by 132 feet (40 meters).
8. At these depths divers may feel euphoria, anxiety, loss of coordination and lack of concentration.
9. At extreme depths, hallucinogenic reaction and tunnel vision can occur.
10. Jacques Cousteau famously described it as the "rapture of the deep".
11. Nitrogen narcosis occurs quickly and the symptoms typically disappear during the ascent, so that divers often fail to realize they were ever affected.
12. It affects individual divers at varying depths and conditions, and can even vary from dive to dive under identical conditions.
13. However, diving with trimix or heliox dramatically reduces the effects of inert gas narcosis.

Category: Sport
Title: Snorkeling
Section: The snorkel

1. A swimmer's snorkel is a tube typically about long and with an inside diameter of between , usually L- or J-shaped and fitted with a mouthpiece at the lower end, and constructed of rubber or plastic.
2. It is used for breathing air from above the water surface when the wearer's mouth and nose are submerged.
3. The snorkel usually has a piece of rubber that attaches the snorkel to the outside of the strap of the diving mask.
4. An older technique is pushing the snorkel between the mask-strap and the head, but this practice increases the chances the mask will leak.The optimum design length of the snorkel tube is at most 40 centimeters (about 16 inches).
5. A longer tube would not allow breathing when snorkelling deeper, since it would place the lungs in deeper water where the surrounding water pressure is higher.
6. The lungs would then be unable to inflate when the snorkeler inhales, because the muscles that expand the lungs are not strong enough to operate against the higher pressure.Snorkels also constitute respiratory dead space.
7. When the user takes in a fresh breath, some of the previously exhaled air which remains in the snorkel is recycled into the lungs, reducing breathing efficiency and causing a build up of carbon dioxide in the blood, which can result in hypercapnia.
8. The greater the volume of the tube, and the smaller the tidal volume of breathing, the more this problem is exacerbated.
9. A smaller diameter tube reduces the dead volume, but also increases resistance to airflow and so increases the work of breathing.
10. Occasional exhalation through the nose while snorkeling will reduce the build up of carbon dioxide, and help in keeping the mask clear of water.

Category: Sport
Title: Snorkeling
Section: Variants and related activities

1. •    Bog snorkelling: An individual sport, popular in the United Kingdom and Australia.
2. •    Finswimming: An individual sport, the most popular competitive sport of CMAS, the only of this federation present in World Games.
3. Finswimmers use a slightly different snorkel, suited for hydrodynamics and speed.
4. •    Free-diving: Any form of diving without breathing apparatus, but often referring to competitive apnea as a sport.
5. •    Scuba diving: A form of untethered diving using a self-contained portable breathing apparatus, frequently as a pastime.
6. •    Spearfishing: Fishing with a spear often with snorkelling equipment, either for competitive sport or to obtain food.
7. •    Underwater hockey: A competitive team-sport played in swimming pools using snorkelling equipment, sticks and a puck.
8. •    Underwater rugby: A competitive team-sport played in deeper swimming pools using snorkelling equipment, baskets and a ball.

Category: Sport
Title: Cricket
Section: Overs

1. The bowler bowls the ball in sets of six deliveries (or "balls") and each set of six balls is called an over.
2. This name came about because the umpire calls "Over!"
3. when six balls have been bowled.
4. At this point, another bowler is deployed at the other end, and the fielding side changes ends while the batsmen do not.
5. A bowler cannot bowl two successive overs, although a bowler can bowl unchanged at the same end for several overs.
6. The batsmen do not change ends and so the one who was non-striker is now the striker and vice-versa.
7. The umpires also change positions so that the one who was at square leg now stands behind the wicket at the non-striker's end and "vice-versa".

Category: Sport
Title: Cricket
Section: Fielding

1. All eleven players on the fielding side take the field together.
2. One of them is the wicket-keeper "aka" "keeper" who operates behind the wicket being defended by the batsman on strike.
3. Wicket-keeping is normally a specialist occupation and his primary job is to gather deliveries that the batsman does not hit, so that the batsmen cannot run byes.
4. He wears special gloves (he is the only fielder allowed to do so), a box over the groin, and pads to cover his lower legs.
5. Owing to his position directly behind the striker, the wicket-keeper has a good chance of getting a batsman out caught off a fine edge from the bat.
6. He is the only player who can get a batsman out stumped.Apart from the one currently bowling, the other nine fielders are tactically deployed by the team captain in chosen positions around the field.
7. These positions are not fixed but they are known by specific and sometimes colourful names such as "slip", "third man", "silly mid on" and "long leg".
8. There are always many unprotected areas.The captain is the most important member of the fielding side as he determines all the tactics including who should bowl (and how); and he is responsible for "setting the field", though usually in consultation with the bowler.In all forms of cricket, if a fielder gets injured or becomes ill during a match, a substitute is allowed to field instead of him.
9. The substitute cannot bowl, act as a captain or keep wicket.
10. The substitute leaves the field when the injured player is fit to return.

Category: Sport
Title: Lacrosse
Section: Box Lacrosse

1. Up until the 1930s, all lacrosse was played on large fields outdoors.
2. The owners of Canadian hockey arenas invented a reduced-size version of the game, called box lacrosse, as a means to make more profit from their arena investments, and because severe winter weather in many areas limits outdoor play.Since 1985, when the Canadian University Field Lacrosse Association (CUFLA) began operating a collegiate men's league, field lacrosse has witnessed a revival in Canada.
3. There are now 12 varsity teams.
4. In 1994, Canada declared lacrosse its national summer sport in the .In 1987, a men's professional box lacrosse league was started, called the Eagle Pro Box Lacrosse League.
5. This league changed its name to the Major Indoor Lacrosse League, then later to the Lacrosse League.
6. It grew to encompass men's lacrosse clubs in 14 cities throughout the United States and Canada.

Category: Sport
Title: Lacrosse
Section: International lacrosse

1. Lacrosse has been played for the most part in Canada and the United States, with small but dedicated lacrosse communities in the United Kingdom and Australia.
2. Recently, however, lacrosse has begun to flourish at an international level, with teams being established particularly in Europe and east Asia.With lacrosse not having been an official Olympic sport since 1908, the pinnacle of international lacrosse competition consists of the quadrennial World Championships.
3. Begun in 1968, world championships began as a four-team invitational tournament sponsored by the International Lacrosse Federation.
4. Until 1986, lacrosse world championships had been contested only by the US, Canada, England, and Australia.
5. Scotland and Wales had teams competing in the women's edition.
6. They are now held for lacrosse at senior men, senior women, under 19 men and under 19 women levels.With the expansion of the game internationally, the 2006 Men's World Championship was contested by 21 countries and the Iroquois Nationals, representing the Six Nations of the Iroquois Confederacy.
7. They are the only Native American/First Nations team to compete internationally.
8. The 2009 Women's World Cup was competed for by 16 nations.In 2003, the first World Indoor Lacrosse Championship was contested by six nations at four sites in Ontario.
9. Canada won the championship in a final game against the Iroquois Nationals, 21-4.
10. The 2007 WILC was held in Halifax from May 14–20, and also won by Canada.
11. Competition included the Iroquois Nationals and teams from Australia, Canada, Czech Republic, England, Ireland, Scotland, and the United States.The World Lacrosse Championships have been dominated by the United States, particularly in the men's game.
12. Its only world championship game losses at either level was in the 1978 final and 2006 final, both to Canada.
13. The USA has won 9 of the 11 senior men's and all six under-19 men's tournaments to date.In the women's game, Australia has provided stiffer competition, having won 6 of 14 games against the USA at senior world championships, including one draw.
14. The USA has won 6 of the 8 senior women's, and 2 of the 3 under-19 women's tournaments to date, with the other world championships won by Australia.The Iroquois Nationals are a team with members representing the Six Nations of the Iroquois Confederacy.
15. The team was admitted to the International Lacrosse Federation (ILF) in 1990.
16. It is the only First Nations team sanctioned to compete in any sport internationally.
17. The Nationals placed fourth in the 1998, 2002 and 2006 World Lacrosse Championships.
18. In 2008, the Iroquois were admitted as the Haudenosunee Nation to the International Federation of Women's Lacrosse Associations (IFWLA), since merged with the FIL (see below).

Category: Sport
Title: Racquetball
Section: Ball Colors

1. Racquetballs are manufactured in a variety of colors such as blue, green, purple, black, red, and pink, and some are for specific purposes (e.g., outdoor play and indoor play), but the differences are unlikely to make much difference for recreational play.
2. Beginners are recommended to use a blue ball by Penn, Ektelon, or Wilson.
3. The blue ball is the most commonly used and it is the most neutral ball for average speed and accuracy of contact.
4. Green balls are similar to blue balls.
5. In the USA the main choices of ball are blue and green for tournament play.
6. In some cases the International Pro Racquetball Tour (IRT) will use a purple Penn HD ball as the official ball.
7. A black ball is often used in tournaments for senior players because the ball is designed to be slower moving and allows for longer rallies.
8. The red ball is the fastest in production and they are known as Red Ektelon Fireballs.
9. This ball is heavier and allows for a quicker pace.
10. The pink ball tends to be the favorite of most recreational players and even some pro level players.
11. This pink ball allows for the highest level of visibility due to the bright pink color.
12. Also, the speed and durability of the ball is very close to that of the blue and green.
13. Finally, the pink ball was created to support breast cancer research and the manufacturers of the ball Wilson, donate $1.00 to the breast cancer awareness association every time a package is sold.Balls do break occasionally, and will lose their bounce over time even without breaking.
14. To keep balls around for a long time it is best to keep them in a room temperature setting and keep them out of extreme cold or heat because this will cause the balls to become less effective and lose their bounce.

Category: Sport
Title: Racquetball
Section: Service

1. Shots of the game.Service.Serve style varies drastically from player to player.
2. Generally, they are divided into two types: offensive and defensive.
3. Most players use an offensive serve for the first serve, and a defensive serve if they need to hit a second serve.
4. Of the offensive serves, the most common is the drive.
5. The intention with this serve is for the ball to travel low and fast towards either back corner, and to bounce twice before striking either side wall or the back wall.
6. If the opponent is adjusting to the drive serve, the server will throw in any variety of jam serves.A "jam serve" is an offensive serve which attempts to catch the opponent off balance by making use of difficult angles and unfrequented play space.
7. The most common jam serve is the Z-serve, which strikes the front wall close to a side wall.
8. The ball bounces quickly off the side wall, then strikes the floor and then the opposite side wall about 30–35 feet back.
9. Depending upon the spin the server gives the Z-serve, the resulting carom may prove unpredictable and difficult to return.
10. Side spin may cause the ball to bounce parallel to the back wall.A "pinch serve" is similar to a drive serve; however, the ball strikes a side wall very low and close to the serving box.
11. With the appropriate spin, the ball has little bounce, and is difficult to return.
12. It is possible that a successful serve would strike the sidewall before the short line, and land on the floor after the short line.If the player faults on the first serve, they will usually hit a defensive serve.
13. Defensive serves do not usually garner aces, but they are designed to generate a weak return by the opponent, thereby setting up the server to win the point.
14. Most defensive serves are any variety of lob serves.
15. A plain lob serve is a ball hit with a long, high arch into either back corner.
16. The goal is to hit the ball so that it lands as close as possible to the back wall, giving the opponent very little room to hit a solid return.
