5. Maple syrup also contains trace amounts of amino acids, which may contribute to the "buddy" flavour of syrup produced late in the season, as the amino acid content of sap increases at this time.
6. Additionally, maple syrup contains a wide variety of volatile organic compounds, including vanillin, hydroxybutanone, and propionaldehyde.
7. It is not yet known exactly what compounds are responsible for maple syrup's distinctive flavour, however its primary flavour contributing compounds are maple furanone, strawberry furanone, and maltol.Maple syrup is similar to sugar with respect to calorie content, but is a source of manganese, with 13 grams containing about 0.44 milligrams, or 22 percent of the US Food and Drug Administration Daily Value (DV%) of 2 milligrams.
8. It is also a source of zinc with 13 grams containing 0.55 milligrams or 3.7 percent of the DV% of 15 milligrams.
9. Compared to honey, maple syrup has 15 times more calcium and 1/10 as much sodium.Scientists have found that maple syrup's natural phenols – potentially beneficial antioxidant compounds – inhibit two carbohydrate-hydrolyzing enzymes that are relevant to type 2 diabetes.
10. In the study, 34 new compounds were discovered in pure maple syrup, five of which have never before been seen in nature.
11. Among the five new compounds is quebecol, a phenolic compound created when the maple sap is boiled to create syrup.British culinary expert Delia Smith described maple syrup as "a unique ingredient, smooth- and silky-textured, with a sweet, distinctive flavour – hints of caramel with overtones of toffee will not do – and a rare colour, amber set alight.
12. Maple flavour is, well, maple flavour, uniquely different from any other."
13. Agriculture Canada has developed a "flavour wheel" that details 91 unique flavours that can be present in maple syrup.
14. These flavours are divided into 13 families: vanilla, empyreumatic (burnt), milky, fruity, floral, spicy, foreign deterioration or environment, maple, confectionery, plants forest-humus-cereals, herbaceous, or ligneous.
15. These flavours are evaluated using a procedure similar to wine tasting.
16. Other culinary experts praise its unique flavour.Maple syrup and its various artificial imitations are widely used as toppings for pancakes, waffles, and French toast in North America.
17. They can also be used to flavour a variety of foods, including fritters, ice cream, hot cereal, fresh fruit, and sausages.
18. It is also used as sweetener for granola, applesauce, baked beans, candied sweet potatoes, winter squash, cakes, pies, breads, tea, coffee, and hot toddies.
19. Maple syrup can also be used as a replacement for honey in wine (mead).

Category: Food
Title: Pho
Section: Etymology and origins

1. Reviews of 19th and 20th century Indochinese literature have found that pho entered the mainstream sometime in the 1910s.
2. Georges Dumoutier's extensive 1907 account of Vietnamese cuisine omits any mention of pho, while Nguyễn Công Hoan recalls its sale by street vendors in 1913.
3. A 1931 dictionary is the first to define ' as a soup: "from the word '.
4. A dish consisting of small slices of rice cake boiled with beef.
5. "Possibly the earliest English-language reference to pho was in the book "Recipes of All Nations", edited by Countess Morphy in 1935: In the book, pho is described as "an Annamese soup held in high esteem ... made with beef, a veal bone, onions, a bayleaf, salt, and pepper, and a small teaspoon of "nuoc-mam"".
6. "There are two prevailing theories on the origin of the word "" and, by extension, the dish itself.
7. As author Nguyễn Dư notes, both questions are significant to Vietnamese identity.

Category: Food
Title: Pho
Section: From Cantonese

1. Hue and Eugèn Gouin (1957) both define ' by itself as an abbreviation of '.
2. Elucidating on the 1931 dictionary, Gouin and Lê Ngọc Trụ (1970) both give ' as a corruption of ' (), which was commonly sold by Chinese immigrants in Hanoi.Some scholars argue that pho (the dish) evolved from ', a Vietnamese dish common in Hanoi at the turn of the century.
3. Originally eaten by commoners near the Red River, it consisted of stir fried strips of water buffalo meat served in broth atop rice vermicelli.
4. Around 1908–1909, the shipping industry brought an influx of laborers.
5. Vietnamese and Chinese cooks set up ' to serve them ' but later switched to inexpensive scraps of beef set aside by butchers who sold to the French.
6. Chinese vendors advertised this ' by crying out, "Beef and noodles!"
7. ().
8. Eventually the street cry became "Meat and noodles!"
9. (), with the last syllable elongated.
10. The French author Jean Marquet spells it "!"
11. in his 1919 novel "Du village-à-la cité".
12. This is likely what the Vietnamese poet Tản Đà calls "" in "" ("Gambling"), written around 1915–1917.

Category: Food
Title: Fajita
Section: Abstract

1. A fajita (; ) is a term found in Tex-Mex cuisine, commonly referring to any grilled meat usually served as a taco on a flour or corn tortilla.
2. The term originally referred to the cut of beef used in the dish which is known as skirt steak.
3. Popular meats today also include chicken, pork, shrimp, and all cuts of beef.
4. In restaurants, the meat is often cooked with onions and bell peppers.
5. Popular condiments are shredded lettuce, sour cream, guacamole, salsa, pico de gallo, cheese, and tomato.
6. The northern Mexican variant of the dish name is Arrachera.

Category: Food
Title: Fajita
Section: Popularity

1. The first culinary evidence of the fajitas with the cut of meat, the cooking style (directly on a campfire or on a grill), and the Spanish nickname going back as far as the 1930s in the ranch lands of South and West Texas.
2. During cattle roundups, beef were butchered regularly to feed the hands.
3. Throwaway items such as the hide, the head, the entrails, and meat trimmings such as skirt were given to the Mexican cowboys called vaqueros as part of their pay.
4. Hearty border dishes like barbacoa de cabeza (head barbecue), menudo (tripe stew), and fajitas or arracheras (grilled skirt steak) have their roots in this practice.
5. Considering the limited number of skirts per carcass and the fact the meat wasn't available commercially, the fajita tradition remained regional and relatively obscure for many years, probably only familiar to vaqueros, butchers, and their families.The food became popular in Tex-Mex restaurants in Houston, Austin, and San Antonio.
6. In southern Arizona, the term was unknown except as a cut of meat until the 1990s, when Mexican fast food restaurants started using the word in their marketing.
7. In recent years, fajitas have become popular at American casual dining restaurants as well as in home cooking.In many restaurants, the fajita meat is brought to the table sizzling loudly on a metal platter or skillet, with the tortillas and condiments.

Category: Food
Title: Lasagne
Section: Abstract

1. Lasagne ( or or , , singular lasagna) are a wide, flat pasta shape, and possibly one of the oldest types of pasta.
2. The word also refers to a dish made with several layers of lasagne sheets alternated with sauces and various other ingredients.Lasagne originated in Italy, traditionally ascribed to the city of Bologna (Emilia-Romagna), in where the first modern receipe was created and published and became a traditional dish.
3. Traditional lasagne is made by interleaving layers of pasta with layers of sauce, made with ragù, bechamel, and Parmigiano-Reggiano.
4. In other regions and outside of Italy it is common to find lasagne made with ricotta or mozzarella cheese, tomato sauce, various meats (e.g., ground beef, pork or chicken), miscellaneous vegetables (e.g., spinach, zucchini, mushrooms) and typically flavored with wine, garlic, onion, and oregano.
5. In all cases the lasagne are oven-baked.Traditionally, pasta dough prepared in Southern Italy used semolina and water and in the northern regions, where semolina was not available, flour and eggs.
6. Today in Italy, since the only type of wheat allowed for commercially sold pasta is durum wheat, commercial lasagne are made of semolina (from durum wheat).Emilio-Romano’s intensive farming economy in the northern region of Italy results in plentiful dairy and meat products, and their commonality in regional cooking – more so than the olive oil found in southern regions of Italy.
7. Pastas from Emilio-Romano and its capital, Bologna, are almost always served with a ragú, a thick sauce made from ingredients such as onions, carrots, finely chopped pork and beef, celery, butter, and tomatoes.

Category: Food
Title: Lasagne
Section: Etymology

1. In the Ancient Rome, there was a dish similar to the lasagne called "lasana" or "lasanum" (Latin word for "container", "pot") described in the book "L'arte culinaria" by Marcus Gavius Apicius, but the word could have a more ancient origin.
2. The first theory is that "lasagne" comes from Greek λάγανον ("laganon"), a flat sheet of pasta dough cut into strips.
3. The word λαγάνα ("lagana") is still used in Greek to mean a flat thin type of unleavened bread.Another theory is that the word lasagne comes from the Greek λάσανα ("lasana") or λάσανον ("lasanon") meaning "trivet or stand for a pot", "chamber pot".
4. The Romans borrowed the word as "lasanum", meaning "cooking pot" in Latin.
5. The Italians used the word to refer to the dish in which lasagne is made.
6. Later the name of the food took on the name of the serving dish.A third theory proposed that the dish is a development of the 14th century English recipe "Loseyn" as described in "The Forme of Cury", a cook book in use during the reign of Richard II.
7. This has similarities to modern lasagne in both its recipe, which features a layering of ingredients between pasta sheets, and its name.
8. An important difference is the lack of tomatoes, which did not arrive in Europe until after Columbus reached America in 1492.
9. The earliest discussion of the tomato in European literature appeared in a herbal written in 1544 by Pietro Andrea Mattioli while the earliest discovered cookbook with tomato recipes was published in Naples in 1692, though the author had apparently obtained these recipes from Spanish sources.As with most other types of pasta, the word is a plural form, "lasagne" meaning more than one sheet of "lasagna".

Category: Food
Title: Chocolate brownie
Section: History

1. A chef at Chicago's Palmer House Hotel created the confection after Bertha Palmer requested a dessert for ladies attending the Chicago 1893 World Fair; it should be, she said, smaller than a piece of cake, though still retaining cake-like characteristics and easily eaten from boxed lunches.
2. These first brownies featured an apricot glaze and walnuts, and they are still being made at the hotel according to the original recipe.The earliest published recipes for a brownie like those of today appeared in the "Home Cookery" (1904, Laconia, NH), "Service Club Cook Book" (1904, Chicago, IL), "The Boston Globe" (April 2, 1905 p. 34) and the 1906 edition of "The Boston Cooking School Cook Book" by Fannie Merritt Farmer.
3. These recipes produced a relatively mild and cake-like brownie.
4. The name "brownie" first appeared in the 1896 version of the cookbook, but this was in reference to molasses cakes baked individually in tin molds, not true brownies.A second recipe appeared in 1907 in "Lowney’s Cook Book", by Maria Willet Howard and published by the Walter M. Lowney Company of Boston, Massachusetts.
5. This recipe added an extra egg and an additional square of chocolate to the Boston Cooking School recipe, creating a richer, fudgier brownie.
6. The recipe was named Bangor Brownies, possibly because it was created by a woman in Bangor, Maine.
7. The Bangor Brownie went on to be rated third in the top 10 snacks a few years later.

Category: Food
Title: Croissant
Section: Abstract

1. A croissant ( or ; ) is a buttery flaky viennoiserie pastry named for its well known crescent shape.
2. Croissants and other viennoiserie are made of a layered yeast-leavened dough.
3. The dough is layered with butter, rolled and folded several times in succession, then rolled into a sheet, in a technique called laminating.
4. The process results in a layered, flaky texture, similar to a puff pastry.Crescent-shaped food breads have been made since the Middle Ages, and crescent-shaped cakes possibly since antiquity.Croissants have long been a staple of French bakeries and pâtisseries.
5. In the late 1970s, the development of factory-made, frozen, pre-formed but unbaked dough made them into a fast food which can be freshly baked by unskilled labor.
6. The croissanterie was explicitly a French response to American-style fast food, and today 30–40% of the croissants sold in French bakeries and patisseries are frozen.
7. Today, the croissant remains popular in a continental breakfast.

Category: Food
Title: Croissant
Section: Origin

1. The Kipferl, ancestor of the croissant, has been documented in Austria going back at least as far as the 13th century, in various shapes.
2. The Kipferl can be made plain or with nut or other fillings (some consider the rugelach a form of Kipferl).The "birth" of the croissant itself – that is, its adaptation from the plainer form of Kipferl, before the invention of Viennoiserie – can be dated with some precision to at latest 1839 (some say 1838), when an Austrian artillery officer, August Zang, founded a Viennese bakery ("Boulangerie Viennoise") at 92, rue de Richelieu in Paris.
3. This bakery, which served Viennese specialities including the Kipferl and the Vienna loaf, quickly became popular and inspired French imitators (and the concept, if not the term, viennoiserie, a 20th-century term for supposedly Vienna-style pastries).
4. The French version of the Kipferl was named for its crescent ("croissant") shape and has become a identifiable shape across the world.Alan Davidson, editor of the "Oxford Companion to Food", found no printed recipe for the present-day croissant in any French recipe book before the early 20th century; the earliest French reference to a croissant he found was among the "fantasy or luxury breads" in Payen's "Des substances alimentaires", 1853.
5. However, early recipes for non-laminated croissants can be found in the nineteenth century and at least one reference to croissants as an established French bread appeared as early as 1850.Zang himself returned to Austria in 1848 to become a press magnate, but the bakery remained popular for some time after, and was mentioned in several works of the time: "This same M. Zank ...founded around 1830 , in Paris, the famous Boulangerie viennoise".
6. Several sources praise this bakery's products: "Paris is of exquisite delicacy; and, in particular, the succulent products of the Boulangerie Viennoise"; "which seemed to us as fine as if it came from the Viennese bakery on the rue de Richelieu".By 1869, the croissant was well established enough to be mentioned as a breakfast staple, and in 1872, Charles Dickens wrote (in his periodical "All the Year Round") of: the workman's pain de ménage and the soldier's pain de munition, to the dainty croissant on the boudoir tableThe puff pastry technique which now characterizes the croissant was already mentioned in the late 17th century, when La Varenne's "Le Cuisinier françois" gave a recipe for it in the 1680 – and possibly earlier – editions.
7. It was typically used, not on its own, but for shells holding other ingredients (as in a vol-au-vent).
8. But it does not appear to be mentioned in relation to the croissant until the twentieth century.

Category: Food
Title: Arepa
Section: Flour

1.
2. "Arepa" flour is specially prepared (cooked in water, then dried) for making "arepas" and other maize dough-based dishes, such as "hallacas", "bollos", "tamales", "empanadas" and "chicha".
3. The most popular brand names of maize flour are Harina PAN in Venezuela and Areparina in Colombia.
4. "Arepa" flour is usually made from white maize, but yellow maize varieties are available.
5. "Arepa" flour was first developed and produced by Empresas Polar of Venezuela, owner of the PAN brand and the primary distributor in the country.

Category: Food
Title: Arepa
Section: Similar dishes

1. In Colombia, the "arepuela" is similar to the traditional "arepa".
2. It is made with wheat flour and sometimes anise, and when fried, the layers expand and the "arepuela" inflates, similar to miniature tortillas or pancakes.
3. This is very common in the interior of Colombia.
4. In the north, "bollos" are popular for breakfast and made with the same dough as an "arepa", but boiled rather than fried, giving them a texture similar to matzo balls or Czech bread dumplings.In Costa Rica, "Arepas" can be made from batter, and may be similar to pancakes.
5. There are at least two sorts, the "pancake" "arepa", which is made with baking powder, and the "big flat" "arepa", which is made without baking powder.
6. These big flat "arepas" are, in size, not unlike the big tortillas one finds in Guanacaste (northern Costa Rica), (i.e.
7. some twelve inches in diameter) and are made of white flour and are sugary.
8. Once perfectly cooked, they should resemble a "giraffe skin", or a "jaguar skin" (i.e., white/yellowish with brown spots).In Mexico, Gorditas are a similar fried dish, but are different from tortillas.In Puerto Rico, "arepas" are made with maize meal, coconut milk, lard, butter, flour, and baking powder.
9. Preparation and cooking varies according to city and family tradition.In El Salvador, Pupusas are similar flat cakes, but the most important difference is the traditional dough is made from nixtamal.
10. It is also filled before it is cooked, usually some pork, white cheese or black beans.
11. Other stypes of "pupusas" are now made from rice dough, particularly in the town called Olocuilta in the department of La Paz.
12. There are also some newer versions of the dish based on plantain dough.

Category: Food
Title: Egg tart
Section: History

1. Custard tarts were introduced in Hong Kong in the 1940s by cha chaan tengs.
2. Which was derived from the original "pastel de nata" ( Portuguese egg tarts ).
3. Egg tarts evolved from the very similar Portuguese egg tart pastries, known as pastel de nata, traveling to Hong Kong via the Portuguese colony of Macau.
4. Hong Kong egg tarts are an adaptation of English custard tarts.
5. Canton (modern Guangdong) had more frequent contact with the West, in particular Britain, than the rest of China.
6. Also, as a former British colony, Hong Kong adopted some British cuisine.

Category: Food
Title: Doughnut
Section: China

1. Asia.China.A few sweet, doughnut-style pastries are regional in nature.
2. Cantonese cuisine features an oval-shaped pastry called "ngàuhleisōu" (牛脷酥, lit.
3. "ox-tongue pastry" due to its tongue-like shape).A spherical food called" saa1 jung" (沙翁) which is also similar to cream puff, but denser in texture (doughnut-like texture) with sugar sprinkled on top, is normally available in Cantonese restaurants in the dim sum style.
4. An oilier Beijing variant of this called 高力豆沙, "gaoli dousha", is filled with red bean paste; originally, it was made with egg white instead of dough.
5. Many Chinese cultures make a chewy doughnut known as "shuangbaotai" (雙包胎), which consists of two conjoined balls of dough.Chinese restaurants in the US sometimes serve small fried pastries similar to doughnut holes, served with condensed milk as a sauce.Chinese cuisine features long, deep-fried doughnut sticks that are often quite oily, hence their name in Mandarin, "yóutiáo" (油條, lit.
6. oil strips.
7. ); in Cantonese, this doughnut-style pastry is called "yàuhjagwái" (油炸鬼, "ghosts fried in oil").
8. These pastries are not sweet and are often served with congee, a traditional rice porridge.

Category: Food
Title: Doughnut
Section: United Kingdom

1. In some parts of Scotland, ring doughnuts are referred to as "doughrings", with the 'doughnut' moniker being reserved exclusively for the nut-shaped variety.
2. Glazed, twisted rope-shaped doughnuts are known as "yum-yums".
3. It is also possible to buy fudge doughnuts in certain regions of Scotland.Also known as doughnoughts, referring to the 'zero' shape or 'nought', being supplied in bakeries and supermarkets.
4. Fillings include jam, custard, cream, sweet mincemeat, chocolate and apple.
5. Common ring toppings are sprinkle-iced and chocolate.In Northern Ireland, ring doughnuts are known as 'gravy rings', gravy being an archaic term for hot cooking oil.

Category: Food
Title: Rendang
Section: Composition and cooking method

1. The cooking technique flourished because of its role in preserving meat in a tropical climate.
2. Rendang is rich in spices.
3. Along with the main meat ingredient, rendang uses coconut milk (Minangkabau: "karambia") and a paste of mixed ground spices, which includes ginger, galangal, turmeric leaves, lemon grass, garlic, shallot, chillies and other spices.
4. This spice mixture is called "pemasak" in Minangkabau.
5. The spices, garlic, shallot, ginger and galangal used in rendang have antimicrobial properties and serve as natural organic preservatives.
6. If cooked properly, dry rendang can last for as long as four weeks.Traditional Padang rendang takes hours to cook.
7. Cooking rendang involves pounding and grinding ingredients as well as slow cooking, and so is time-consuming and requires patience.
8. The meat pieces are slowly cooked in coconut milk and spices until almost all the liquid is gone, allowing the meat to absorb the condiments.
9. The cooking process changes from boiling to frying as the liquid evaporates.
10. The slow cooking process allows the meat to absorb all the spices and to become tender.
11. To cook the meat until tender, with almost all liquids evaporated, requires great care, if the meat is not to burn or be spoiled.
12. Because of its generous use of numerous spices, rendang is known for having a complex and unique taste.Rendang is often served with steamed rice, "ketupat" (a compressed rice cake), or "lemang" (glutinous rice barbecued in bamboo tubes), accompanied with vegetable side dishes such as boiled cassava leaf, "cubadak" (young jackfruit gulai), cabbage gulai, and "lado" (red or green chilli pepper sambal).

Category: Food
Title: Rendang
Section: Cultural significance

1. Rendang is revered in Minangkabau culture as an embodiment of the philosophy of "musyawarah", discussion and consultation with elders.
2. It has been claimed that the four main ingredients represent Minangkabau society as a whole :
3. •     The meat ("dagiang") symbolizes the "Niniak Mamak", the traditional clan leaders, such as the datuk, the nobles, royalty and revered elders.
4. •     The coconut milk ("karambia") symbolizes the "Cadiak Pandai", intellectuals, teachers, poets and writers.
5. •     The chili ("lado") symbolizes the "Alim Ulama", clerics, "ulama" and religious leaders.
6. The hotness of the chili symbolizes sharia.
7. •     The spice mixture ("pemasak") symbolizes the rest of Minangkabau society.

8. In Minangkabau tradition, rendang is a requisite dish for special occasions in traditional Minang ceremonies, from birth ceremonies to circumcision, marriage, Qur'an recitals and religious festivals such as Eid ul-Fitr and Eid ul-Adha.

Category: Food
Title: Peking duck
Section: Raising the duck

1. Preparation.Raising the duck.The ducks used to prepare Peking Duck originated in Nanjing.
2. They were small, had black feathers, and lived in the canals around the city linking major waterways.
3. With the relocation of the Chinese capital to Beijing, supply barge traffic increased in the area.
4. Often these barges would spill grain into the canals, providing food for the ducks.
5. By the Five Dynasties, the new species of duck had been domesticated by Chinese farmers.
6. Nowadays, Peking Duck is prepared from the Pekin duck ("Anas platyrhynchos domestica").
7. Newborn ducks are raised in a free range environment for the first 45 days of their lives, and force fed 4 times a day for the next 15–20 days, resulting in ducks that weigh 5–7 kg (11–15 lbs).
8. The force feeding of the ducks led to an alternate name for the dish, Peking Stuffed Duck ().

Category: Food
Title: Peking duck
Section: Reheating

1. Whole Peking Ducks can be ordered as takeaways.
2. The ducks can be reheated at home with an oven, grill or boiling oil.
3. When an oven is used, the duck is heated at a temperature of 150 °C (300 °F) for 20 minutes, and then at 160 °C (325 °F) for another 10 minutes.
4. The grilling method involves filling the duck with boiling water before placing it on a griddle, 70 cm (28 in) above the cooking fire.
5. The boiling water is replaced every 3–4 minutes until the duck's skin is piping hot.
6. To reheat the Peking Duck with oil, the duck is sliced into thin pieces and placed in a strainer held over a wok of boiling oil.
7. The duck is then rinsed several times with the oil.

Category: Food
Title: Sushi
Section: Nigirizushi

1.
2. "Nigirizushi" (, "hand-pressed sushi") consists of an oblong mound of "sushi rice" that the chef presses into a small rectangular box between the palms of the hands, usually with a bit of "wasabi", and a topping (the "neta") draped over it.
3. "Neta" are typically fish such as salmon, tuna or other seafood.
4. Certain toppings are typically bound to the rice with a thin strip of "nori", most commonly octopus ("tako"), freshwater eel ("unagi"), sea eel ("anago"), squid ("ika"), and sweet egg ("tamago").
5. "Gunkanmaki" (, "warship roll") is a special type of "nigirizushi": an oval, hand-formed clump of sushi rice that has a strip of "nori" wrapped around its perimeter to form a vessel that is filled with some soft, loose or fine-chopped ingredient that requires the confinement of "nori" such as roe, "nattō", oysters, "uni" (sea urchin roe), corn with mayonnaise, scallops, and quail eggs.
6. "Gunkan-maki" was invented at the "Ginza Kyubey" restaurant in 1941; its invention significantly expanded the repertoire of soft toppings used in sushi.
7. "Temarizushi" (, "ball sushi") is a ball-shaped sushi made by pressing rice and fish into a ball-shaped form by hand using a plastic wrap.

Category: Food
Title: Sushi
Section: Western-style sushi

1. The increasing popularity of "sushi" around the world has resulted in variations typically found in the Western world, but rarely in Japan (a notable exception to this is the use of salmon which was introduced by the Norwegians in the early 1980s).
2. Such creations to suit the Western palate were initially fueled by the invention of the California roll (a "norimaki" with crab (later, imitation crab), cucumber, and avocado).
3. A wide variety of popular rolls ("norimaki" and "uramaki") has evolved since.
4. Though the menu names of dishes often vary by restaurant, some examples include:Other rolls may include pretty much anything, including chopped scallops, spicy tuna, beef or chicken teriyaki roll, okra, and assorted vegetables such as cucumber and avocado.
5. Since rolls are usually made to-order, it is not unusual for the customer to specify the exact ingredients desired.
6. Sometimes, rolls are made with brown rice or black rice, which appear in Japanese cuisine as well.
7. An "uramaki" (inside-out roll) allows draping ingredients on the outside of the roll in addition to the inside.
8. Examples include the rainbow roll (an inside-out topped with thinly sliced "maguro, hamachi, ebi, sake" and avocado) and the caterpillar roll (an inside-out topped with thinly sliced avocado).
9. Also commonly found is the "rock and roll" (an inside-out roll with barbecued freshwater eel and avocado with toasted sesame seeds on the outside) and the "tempura roll", where shrimp tempura is inside the roll or the entire roll is battered and fried tempura-style.
10. In the Southern United States, many sushi restaurants prepare rolls using crawfish.
11. "Futomaki" roll is found widely within Japan.
12. Other types of Western-style sushi are also rarely seen in Japan.

Category: Food
Title: Curry
Section: Curries of Maharashtra

1. The curries of Maharashtra vary from mildly spicy to very spicy and include vegetarian, mutton, chicken and fish.
2. Coastal Maharashtrian – Konkani – curries use coconut extensively along with spices.
3. In western Maharashtra, curries are very spicy and groundnut (peanut) powder is often added to it.
4. Vidarbha's cuisine is usually spicier than that of the coastal and southern regions.
5. The ingredients commonly used are besan, or chickpea flour, and groundnut powder.
6. As a result of the long Islamic Moghul rule in the region, the cuisine of Aurangabad has been highly influenced by the North Indian method of cooking.
7. Khandeshi food is very spicy and the most famous dish is Shev bhaji.
8. Others include brinjal wange, che bharit, Udidachi dal, Bharleli wangi, thecha bhakari, and spicy mutton.
9. Most of the people are farmers so their traditional food is very simple.

Category: Food
Title: Curry
Section: Curries of Punjab

1. Punjab is a rich agricultural land, where fresh vegetables and fruits have always been accessible.
2. A typical Punjabi meal consists of some form of bread or rice with a "salan" (curry).
3. Most preparations start with the frying of a masala which is a concoction of ginger, garlic, onions and tomatoes with some dried spices.
4. This is followed by the addition of other ingredients.
5. Spice level varies greatly depending on the sub-region as well as the household itself.
6. A popular cooking fat is pure desi ghee, and some dishes are often enriched with liberal amounts of butter and cream.
7. There are certain dishes that are exclusive to Punjab, such as maash di dal and saron da saag (sarson ka saag).

Category: Food
Title: Bibimbap
Section: History

1.
2. "Bibimbap" is first mentioned in the "Siuijeonseo", an anonymous cookbook from the late 19th century.
3. There its name is given as 부븸밥 ("bubuimbap").
4. Some scholars assert that bibimbap originates from the traditional practice of mixing all the food offerings made at an ancestral rite ("jesa") in a bowl before partaking in it.In Korean households, "bibimbap" is frequently prepared from steamed rice, vegetables, and meat.Since the late 20th century, "bibimbap" has become widespread in different countries, due to its convenience of preparation.
5. It is also served on many airlines connecting to South Korea.

Category: Food
Title: Bibimbap
Section: Variations

1. A variation of this dish, "dolsot bibimbap" (돌솥 비빔밥, "dolsot" meaning "stone pot"), is served in a very hot stone bowl in which a raw egg is cooked against the sides of the bowl.
2. The bowl is so hot that anything that touches it sizzles for minutes.
3. Before the rice is placed in the bowl, the bottom of the bowl is coated with sesame oil, making the layer of the rice touching the bowl golden brown and crisp.The city of Jeonju, the capital of the North Jeolla Province of South Korea, is famous throughout the nation for its version of "bibimbap", said to be based on a royal court dish of the Joseon Dynasty.A further variation of "bibimbap", called "hoedeopbap", uses a variety of raw seafood, such as tilapia, salmon, tuna or sometimes octopus, but each bowl of rice usually contain one kind of meat.
4. The term "hoe" in the word means raw fish.
5. The dish is popular along the coasts of Korea where fish are abundant.

Category: Food
Title: Galbi
Section: Abstract

1. Kalbi or galbi generally refers to a variety of "gui" or grilled dishes in Korean cuisine that are made with marinated beef (or pork) short ribs in a "ganjang"-based sauce (Korean soy sauce).
2. In the Korean language, "galbi" literally means "rib" and can refer to cooked or uncooked ribs.
3. Although the dish's full name is galbi gui, the word ""gui"" (grilling) is commonly omitted.
4. Suwon and Los Angeles are particularly known for their galbi.
5. "Galbi" is generally made with beef ribs, and it may be called ""sogalbi"" (소갈비) or ""soegalbi"" (쇠갈비).
6. The prefix ""so"" or ""soe"" (beef) is often omitted when referring to beef ribs.
7. It is also called "bulgalbi" when grilled over fire.
8. "Galbi" can also be made with pork ribs or chicken; in such cases, the dish is called ""dwaeji galbi"" (돼지갈비) or ""dak galbi"" (닭갈비) to emphasize the main ingredient.It is listed at number 41 on the "World's 50 most delicious foods" readers' poll complied by "CNN Go" in 2011.

Category: Food
Title: Galbi
Section: History

1. The ingredients (often, ribs or meats) are marinated in a sauce made primarily from soy sauce, garlic, and sugar.
2. However, several variations on the marinade exist, including recipes that utilize sesame oil, rice wine or hot pepper paste.
3. Fruit juice, lemon-lime soda and honey have become more common additions to Korean marinades in recent years, and is present in some incarnations of the dish.
4. When cooked on a griddle or grill, the meat is usually cut in thin slices across the bones.
5. This style of cut, called L.A. Galbi, permits the marinade to penetrate the meat faster.
6. It also allows the meat to cook more quickly, creates a more tender cut, and makes it easier to eat the finished dish with chopsticks.
7. The traditional cut is called Wang Galbi, literally meaning King Ribs.
8. In this version, the ribs are cut into 2 to 5 inch segments, and the meat is filleted in layers away from the bone to form a uniformly thin layer.
9. Wang Galbi is usually what is served in traditional Korean restaurants, as the traditional cut is considered more genuine.
10. Rarely, if ever, are L.A. Galbi served at top establishments.
11. Pre-cut galbi is available from many meat markets in Korea and elsewhere.
12. "Galbi" is generally served in restaurants known as "galbi houses", and the meat is cooked right at customers' tables on grills set in the tables (usually by the customers themselves).
13. It is typically served with lettuce, perilla, or other leafy vegetables used to wrap the meat, which is then dipped in "ssamjang" (쌈장), a sauce made of fermented bean paste and red pepper paste.
14. It is often accompanied by side dishes known as banchan.
15. Many Korean dishes incorporate ribs, including soups and stews.
16. Some restaurants serve "pork galbi", and chicken galbi is a specialty of the Chuncheon region.
17. "Galbitang" is a clear soup containing pieces of "galbi".
18. "Galbi jjigae" is a thick stew with many large pieces of galbi, usually single bone cuts, which may also contain red peppers, green peppers, kimchi, and "doenjang" (Korean bean paste).
19. "Galbi Jjim" is short ribs braised in a sweet soy sauce based sauce.

Category: Food
Title: Bulgogi
Section: Preparation and serving

1.
2. "Bulgogi" is made from thin slices of sirloin or other prime cuts of beef.
3. Before cooking, the meat is marinated to enhance its flavour and tenderness with a mixture of soy sauce, sugar, sesame oil, garlic, pepper and other ingredients such as scallions, ginger, onions or mushrooms, especially white button mushrooms or "matsutake".
4. Sometimes, cellophane noodles are added to the dish, which varies by the region and specific recipe.
5. "Bulgogi" is traditionally grilled, but pan-cooking has become popular as well.
6. Whole cloves of garlic, sliced onions and chopped green peppers are often grilled or fried with the meat.
7. This dish is sometimes served with a side of lettuce or other leafy vegetable, which is used to wrap a slice of cooked meat, often along with a dab of "ssamjang", or other side dishes, and then eaten together.

Category: Food
Title: Bulgogi
Section: In modern culture

1.
2. "Bulgogi" is served in barbecue restaurants in Korea, and there are "bulgogi" flavoured fast-food hamburgers sold at many South Korean fast-food restaurants.
3. The hamburger patty is marinated in "bulgogi" sauce and served with lettuce, tomato, onion, and sometimes cheese.
4. It is similar to a teriyaki burger in flavour.The October 2011 issue of Jamie magazine featured a stall selling bulgogi steak baguettes outside Arsenal FC's Emirates Stadium.
5. The same stall was featured in Nicholas Lander's food column in the Financial Times in October 2012.Texas Rangers outfielder Shin-Soo Choo endorsed bulgogi in an advertisement in the March 12th, 2014 issue of The New York Times.

Category: Food
Title: Shabu-shabu
Section: History

1.
2. "Shabu-shabu" was introduced in Japan in the 20th century with the opening of the restaurant "Suehiro"[http://www.e-suehiro.com/history/] in Osaka, where the name was invented.
3. Its origins are traced back to the Chinese hot pot known as "shuan yang rou".
4. "Shabu-shabu" is most similar to the original Chinese version when compared to other Japanese dishes ("nabemono") such as "sukiyaki" .
5. Suehiro registered the name as a trademark in 1955.
6. Together with "sukiyaki", "shabu-shabu" is a common dish in tourist hot-spots, especially in Tokyo, but also in local Japanese neighborhoods (colloquially called "Little Tokyos") in countries such as the United States and Canada.

Category: Food
Title: Shabu-shabu
Section: Preparation

1. The dish was originally made with thinly sliced beef , but some versions use pork, crab, chicken, lamb, duck, or lobster.
2. Most often, ribeye steak is used, but less tender cuts, such as top sirloin, are also common.
3. A more expensive meat, such as "wagyū", may also be used.
4. It is usually served with tofu and vegetables, including Chinese cabbage, chrysanthemum leaves, "nori" (edible seaweed), onions, carrots, shiitake mushrooms and enokitake mushrooms.
5. In some places, "udon", "mochi" or "harusame" noodles may also be served.The dish is prepared by submerging a thin slice of meat or a piece of vegetable in a pot of boiling water or "dashi" (broth) made with "konbu" (kelp) and stirring it.
6. Cooked meat and vegetables are usually dipped in "ponzu" or "goma" (sesame seed) sauce before eating, and served with a bowl of steamed white rice.
7. Once the meat and vegetables have been eaten, leftover broth from the pot is customarily combined with the remaining rice, and the resulting soup is usually eaten last.
